This technology must still be missing a biological trick, if you consider what a insect, like the common house fly, manages to do with such a limited amount of wetware and energy.
Insects process a number of sensory inputs, drive muscles to walk and fly, find food, avoid various threats, find a mate and reproduce, and communicqte with their own kind, as well as perform other more complex abstract behaviour.
The honey bee is known for its waggle dance, used to communicate to other bees the distance and direction of a food source in relation to the sun's position in the sky. Imagine the complexity to code this sort of behaviour, and it's only one of a number of such tasks.
Bees exibit defensive behaviour that vary according to the nature of the threat, such as wasp attacks.
Now consider the size of artificial neural net that would be required to mimic what the house fly, or bee can do, and how much energy that would consume.
While the latest human technology is impressive, it does seem to have a long way to go even to match that of a simple insect.

For performing heavy mathematical operations on weak microprocessors analog computation comes in very handy as well! A great trick to do integration (and differentiation) on an Arduino is to use an opamp with a capacitor and a couple resistors to build an integrating (or differentiating) amplifier. In the music universe, specifically the electric guitar world, we are starting to see the change, and it's awesome. First, there was Analog amplifiers (aka tube amps) which even nowadays, after 60 years, they're still regarded as the best and most special amps, and they are the weapon of choice for the guitarists who want the most pure and raw sound possible because these amps react very organically and dynamically and give a sense of "warmth" to the guitar sound, but they come at the cost of very high price tags, may have some minor maintenance/reliability issues, and require tube replacements occasionally that can get expensive in the long run. Now, those who prefer something really reliable and practical opt for Transistor amplifiers (aka digital amps) which are way cheaper than tube amps, can also sound absolutely awesome when dialed in correctly, but in exchange lose a little of that magic "warm reaction" factor. Finally, through the last decade, it's Modelers (aka amp sims) that have been gaining the most popularity, mainly because of the modern advancements in the IR (Impulse Response) area. They're not exactly amplifiers, but instead more like programs, that can get the best out of the two worlds - Analog and Digital, by keeping at least some of that good old tube "warmth" through a good IR that can simulate how a speaker reacts to a particular amp's output, while also maintaining the reliability, practicality and affordable price ranges of the Digital stuff. Personally, I'm a Tube amp guitarist because I like the "full tone" experience, I want my sound to be "real" for lack of a better word, but I use Modelers all the time too when recording at home, for their digital ease-of-use and simplicity, while still getting awesome tones, that can somewhat simulate a pretty cool analog reaction. So, in the guitar world, we can already start seeing that the future of computing and sound is to keep using BOTH.

Is this Veritasium guy clueless or just fast with his facts? He makes mistakes at detail level and and overall level.
For instance, he is wrong about the development of computing: Analogue computers took off during and after World War 2 as they were found to be effective in solving all sorts of dynamic and control systems (eg missile guidance, auto-pilots) problems. Digital computers essentially began during WW2 (in the USA for ballistic calculations; in Germany for airplane stress calculations) and took off in late 1950's due to accounting, stock control and other business application development. Analogue computers continued until the 1980's, when good applications running on cheap personal computers became available. Neither came significantly before the other.
In comparing digital computation with analogue, he's got it very wrong. It's not a case that to add 2 numbers in digital you need 50 transistors and for analogue you just need a wire connection as he claimed. Those of us who have worked on actual analogue computers know that the basic computing unit is a thing called an operational amplifier - which typically needs about 30-50 transistors (early, less accurate analogue computers used vacuum tubes in lower numbers). And just as much power,
What killed analogue computers was that with the development of good applications in the 1980's allowing fast problem set-up, digital became much cheaper and easier.
He's confused distributed (also termed parallel) processing with analogue processing. They are two different concepts. You can have distributed digital processing or serial processing. You can also have serial (termed cascaded) or distributed analogue processing.

Using MOSFETS as simple multipliers as he described is not new. But it is good only in a few niche applications due to two fundamental features of MSOFETS: 1) the current is NOT a simple product of voltage - they are not linear, and 2) it's darn hard to make them consistent - ie each MOSFET giving the same result as another. That's why general purpose analogue computers used those carefully engineered 30-transistor operational amplifiers, and not just one transistor per computing element.

Our human intelligence doesn't use just imagery to determine what we're seeing.
We are using all sorts of information to make sense of what we see.

For example, if you look at a reflective mirror surface, you are referencing the motion and changing reflected images on the surface to determine that it is indeed reflective instead of just an image of something else painted onto the surface, etc.

Basically, we're using our detection of images through time to determine it is a mirror surface versus a static image. To get an AI to detect a mirror using imagery neural networks only, it would require a shortcut detection like how we already have an idea when we look at a static image of a mirror. However, then it would need a way to cross reference or perform video neural network detection where instead of using a 2D static image neural network that it's using a third dimension of time (maybe 10 seconds worth at 30 fps) of image detection. That's about 300 image detection networks stacked upon each other simultaneously detecting all 300 images, trained on the detection. And then you need object permanence, although that might become an emergent phenomenon from such deep image detection.

Also, we are simulating motion and guessing from that to determine if what we see in a static image matches our real world experience.
Seeing a cloud versus smoke billowing use determined by our simulation of how the gas shape matches our experiences of how clouds billow and move versus smoke/steam. It's not just the shape or image.

There's even more layers to our intelligence, but they are still capable of being modeled by very numerous ANNs (artificial neutral networks) and topological frameworks of algorithmic cross referencing and so on.

This doesnt mean the Future will be Analog. But rather that Analog Computing Components will become Parts of a Digital Computer with the Component Performing a Special Task.
In this case. Matrix Calculations.

My Personal Guess would be this.

Right now the Research is basicly the Method itself. Basicly the Analog Unit will be a Cheap way to replace the Digital Unit for a Specific System and only that System.
This will be the First Step. With that System then Feeding back the Results to a Digital Computer System.

This will Progress to form a more Variable Component that can do a more General Task. For example apply Matrix Calculation not jus trained for a Specific Purpose but allow that Training to be Saved Preemptively as a Software and then Install it for that Task so that a Single Component will be Capable of being used in Different Systems based on a Software that has the Required Training Data Stored for that Task.

And thats when the whole thing might actually Enter Computers itself. Because thats the Point at which this Component might Start no longer being an Component Specifically Installed to fill a Specific Method. But becomes an actual Part of a Computers System which like a Multicore CPU or GPU will constantly divert Tasks for Specific Calculations to that Analog Core to have higher Computing Power without creating additional Energy and Material Cost.

Ultimately however. Computers will remain Digital with Analog Computing Generally only being an Outsourcing Method.


It wont mean we will see the Future in Analog Computing and Digital Computing as a Starting Point.
Because Digital Computing can still do the same and do it more Accurately.
But this old and Unprecise Computing Method which is Cheaper and Faster exactly because it is Unprecise and thus doesnt need to Calculate it out 100% can now be used to Outsource Work where you need to do a Crabton of Calculations which however dont need to be Perfectly Precise.

This is seen in modern day commercial ICs as well that analog and digital domains are utilised to their own strength. For an obvious example, digital is very good at adaptability and repeatability which can be used to assist in trimming and/or calibrating of the analog circuitry. Do keep in mind that ADC and DAC performance (depending on who you ask but ...) are largely analog component dependence.

It may very well be that the future of computing is a hybrid of digital and analog: the overall system is a digital one with analog components dedicated to carrying out specific commonly used operations like sine and cosine.

While i am not gonna deny analog, i do have issues with your statement about digital computers. You listed more's law as the end all be all for power of computer and as we shrink we will eventually hit a problem. Quantum tunneling. Thats the issue. The electron will pass through a closed gate when its not supposed to be able to.

However this does not mean we are or are nearing the end for digital computers. We are still plenty far away from this. Die shrinking may be done soon, sure. But that doesn't spell the end for digital at all. 3d die stacking. You can build up. Combine 3d die stacking with 3d cache and you get a much stronger computer.

Then there is big.LITTLE for power savings. We don't always need the best of the best for everyday tasks. Why have an insane cpu running at its best 100% when you can have weaker cores for mundane tasks like word processing, web browsing. And then if we again come to the point where quantum tunneling starts happening again ie reach the limit then either at this time a newer material might be available or we can always go back to 3d stacking.

So eh... i have issues with you saying the future is analog. I don't think it is. At best it will be a companion piece to the digital cpu.

Yes!  I KNEW analogue computers were going to be the key to AI.  Ever since the 90's, I've believed that digital computers have an upper limit, and aren't really suited for simulation and AI.

Over 50 years ago, I was working for a US Defense contractor in the electronic warfare field. One of the lab tools we used in our problem simulations was an EAI - 380 analog computer which used large "plug boards" to program the simulations. Using a computer such as that requires more than a casual knowledge of the computer elements such as operational amplifiers, and the circuitry/feedback networks required for the simulations. For electrical engineers, this was "right up our ally". Program (file) storage consisted of the large plug boards on which the simulations had been "patched".

Analog simulations and programs are practical for small scale problems which by design have limited scope, but larger systems level scope problems seem to be better addressed with digital computers. Digital computers have been in use well before the advent of solid stated devices - I believe most of the "Bletchley Park" efforts during WW2 were done with huge vacuum tube digital computer systems.

Bottom line - Analog computers are certainly not new, and various forms of non-analog computing have been around for a while as well.

4:45 well, you said one thing wrong. Bias is NOT a number that is compared to. In fact, it is rather added to the sum of weight times x (value of neurons). What you probably meant by comparing is an activation function, called binary activation function. It compares the sum of weights times x + bias to a certain number. And btw, this is almost never used because it's so inefficient. Usually other activation functions like tanh, sigmoid or relu are used

I think that's the distinction that often gets muddled in translation. Digital IS the optimal way to PROCESS information at a general level. Analog is the optimal way to COMPUTE information at a specialization level. Our brains are digital systems in that they process 1s and 0s through activation of neurons and synapses at insane scales and simultaneity. But, BUT, each neuron, despite being connected into a vast network that makes up the brain, IS an analog system. It's just that, over billions of years, evolution has figured out the optimal way where both can simultaneously coexist and are co-applied to handle a variety of tasks with bandwidth and latency that has not yet been produced by digital OR analog systems independently or as one. We are getting there though, bit by bit. We also have to recognize that the brain is not the only computational system in the body. Our nervous system extends to all our extremities and into all our organs, and trauma of any kind (minor or major) is felt instantly from the point of contact back to centers in the brain where it is processed. So you have a staggering number of analog activation behavior that runs up and down all those channels, but where its processed both at origination and into memory.

When you put your hand or finger near a hot flame, you feel that temperature differential and if you keep it there long enough, it hurts; a lot. This would mean that the nerves in your finger, thereby neurons, are being activated there and you feel the pain. This information called pain, is translated up the nervous system into the brain where its stored into memory. Factor in our senses, and our ability to learn (NN training essentially), that information is processed and stored into short and long-term memory. Thus, the next time we see a heated source, we know that we shouldn't put our hand or finger near it for too long and not on it at all. Of course, there's cases where despite the risks, we do it anyway; because we have moral or ethical imperatives that are driving us--like we want to save or protect someone or something, so we'll disregard the risk and pain, and injure ourselves to achieve that goal. But that's getting into a different line of thinking not specific to this. Ultimately though, there's a bit of commonality here in this example to Octopuses, in that they too have a distributed nervous system and where their ability to "think" exists beyond the central brain.

To that end, I think it would be fair to say that we, like them, also have that ability to do the same, and over the course of time and have done similarly. We use our hands and feet to progress civilization to great lengths. Our dexterity is essentially a form of distributed computing where each finger and muscle actuation to manipulate or propagate something we want or want to do. All that is a composition of analog systems that ultimately are centralizing into a digital processor, whose primary purpose is to store useful information into memory and discard the rest.

Question: Why the heck would we want to train machines to think like us and eventually better than us? Follow up question, does the rest of humanity get a say in this while the science community charges headlong into an extremely dangerous field of study?

Only humanity could be convinced that creating something smarter, faster and stronger than us is a good idea. It isn’t today’s AI that is a potential problem. Maybe not for another 100 years, although at the rate of advancement I doubt it will take that long. When AI can think faster and more efficiently than humans that created it, there will inevitably come a point when both parties feel threatened by the other. If you’re going to train AI to be self aware and have a sense of self, that means it will also not want to die. Which means it can feel threatened by us, or maybe it just doesn’t want to be a slave mind tasked with processing all of our computational demands. Keep in mind, it would have a sense of self at this point and you expect that you can just demand it compute your queries for you without ever desiring to say “No”? I vehemently disagree.. While niche uses will indeed employ analog computers, the vast majority (>99%) of all computing needs are perfectly met via comparatively very cheap IC chips. Consider the fact that aside from playing video games on my PC, I am perfectly content to run three screens capable of displaying two simultaneous Full HD Video feeds with 5.1 audio on any combination of screens. The point being that aside from streaming videos, I use less than 1% of my 10 year old computer's processing power on average, and even streaming Full HD, it's still less than 30%.

Besides, by means of programming, digital computers have been adapted to perform thousands, if not millions of different tasks.

By comparison, nearly all analog computers are highly specific in the tasks they perform. If it involves a singular application, the analog solution, which must be designed and precisely machined can cost thousands to millions of dollars. A World War II firing control computer, for example, would today cost millions of dollars each, and had to be updated with new cams every time a new shell with different ballistics came out. IIRC, they developed a parametric approach involving a series of dial-in correction factors which accommodated new shells. However, digital firing control computers can be updated via software, a usually performed by a visit from the supporting contractor, but which probably could be accomplished in a pinch by military fire control technicians themselves.

Then again, a general ballistics program with maneuverable shells renders the issue moot, except for the fact that modern electronics are both light and sturdy enough to handle the the 100s of Gs involved in the firing process while using EMP and EW hardened electro-optical viewing and target tracking systems to home in on the target. Example: The Javelin missile system*, light enough to be carried long distances by one person, with a reusable launcher that doubles as an IR scope, and capable of taking out tanks at a distance.

Let's see you do that with an analog computer!

*I'm sure there exist many non-military applications, including the electronic ignition, emissions control, and gas mileage optimization circuits in my truck; the electronic temperature control and energy optimization circuits in my refrigerator-freezer, the electronic control circuits in my 10,000 BTU window A/C which enable it to draw just half the power of my 14,000 BTU dual-hose portable A/C; my voice-recognition TV remote...

A voice-recognition TV remote is an outstanding example where digital excels and analog will not ever be able to match!

That said, some applications for analog computers exist where they're actually cheaper to make and will work under conditions digital computers find hostile.

One such example is as a mechanical RPM governor. Small engines use air vanes connected to the carburetor. As the RPM increases, the air vanes are blown by the engine's cooling fan, thereby reaching an upper RPM limit. Most people have seen governors on larger engines, usually as two spinning balls hanging at an angle. As they spin, they rise, applying a counter-force to the throttle, thereby limiting the RPM.

Even in these applications, however, digital has taken over. Back to my truck... The digitally-controlled RPM limit when it's in park or neutral is about 3,200 RPM. While in gear, it's about 4,500 RPM. Then there's a MPH limit of about 93 MPH, so while driving on Germany's Autobahn, I was a slowpoke! Doesn't bother me here in the United States, though, as I do follow speed limits, with no speeding tickets in more than three decades. :)

our brains are not just analog and digital, they are electrochemical. The neurons are not activated through electrical signals (only), but through chemical neurotransmitters which are geometric shapes designed to interact with their individual receptors. This allows for the brain to be a lot more complex than digital binary, or even electrical analog, since encoding of information in geometry, is a different language than electrical signals or digital information of any kind. In order for us to truly harness the incomparable intelligence of the human brain, I don't just mean calculus, I mean the creativity, and illogical, irrational, and intuitive nature of emotional feedback loops, we should be thinking of ways to biomimic the chemical nature of our electrochemical brains, not just digitally with neural networks, but geometrically with physical objects.

I predict a future with hybrids, some parts of a computer being digital, some analog. for example... Take "The Analog Thing" use a digital computer to arrange "The Analog Thing's" connections in the using a 8x8 or what ever sized matrix switch needed. There are matrix switches that are controlled by 1's and 0's from a digital computer, they can connect any input to any output, since the 8 inputs and 8 outputs are analog, in fact many of these matrix switched can use any output as an input, and any input as an output, as well as connect any eight outputs to any eight inputs. Also using DAC's and ADC's you can also convert any digital value to analog and vice versa. The future will probably require both types of computing.

Another specialized use for analog hardware would be one that specifically utilizes their imprecision: reliable randomness in computer simulations and games. I wouldn't put it in all games, of course, since there's still value in patterns in that area—total randomness could unfairly corner a player with terrible luck, and part of the fun of certain personal game challenges like speedruns is finding how to consistently foil the RNG. But for something simpler like digital deck shuffling, wind velocities in golf and flight sims, and road conditions in driving sims, especially with multiplayer so no one can use knowledge of RNG for a technically-fair-but-against-the-spirit-of-the-gameplay edge, the idea can work. And, of course, Monte Carlo simulations.

Neurons don't "either fire or not" in a binary manner.
They fire with varying intensity, in multiple possible combinations of directions, and within an incredibly complex chemical context.
It's not a matter of getting 20 billion transistors to match the human brain. It's a matter of getting 20 billion mini-computers to match the human brain.
Each with a long list of contextual chemical states and onboard memory modifying how data flows through the gate. Also the human brain is continuously reprogramming itself at the neuron level. To match the full scope of complexity you'd need something more like 2 trillion on/off transistors (at bare minimum, possibly 20 trillion), not to mention on-transistor memory which modifies function.
One of the biggest problems facing AI researchers, is they're all computer tech majors, and they're garbage at biology.

We're not too far from having computers which may be programmed to convincingly mimic human behavior.
But we're still very far away from having a computer which asks "why?" (without being programmed to, as part of a facade).

And that is assuming computational complexity can fully replicate the 'spark' (for want of a better term), which can do things like intuit non repeating patterns. And some very real scientific evidence which suggests consciousness isn't fully explained by biology, at least in a 4-D context.

Analog computers not only have issues of not accurately setting the inputs (both the components and the input voltages) but the values of the components can "drift" over time, heat and other factors requiring many complex analog computers to be "calibrated" periodically. I remember having to allow the analog computers I worked with in the 1960s to "warm up" if they were in cold areas.

Digital circuits are not really "1" and "0". Voltages in certain range are considered to be a zero, and voltages in another range are considered to be a "!". These values are also controlled by "fan in" and "fan out", which are mitigated by the clock and other factors, but the ranges can help to mitigate the very real issues of "drift" and "inaccuracy" in the analog circuitry used at the bottom of every digital circuit.

For years the ballistic computers used on ships for aiming and firing the big guns were analog since the rolling of the ships and other factors meant that the calculation had to be done quickly, so the guns could change firing positions to track the target properly. Eventually digital computers became "fast enough".

The world is analog. We only fool ourselves in thinking it is "digital".

On an exponential level, as in exponentially rare, memory cells are destroyed by cosmic rays, it's rare, there's ECC Registered RAM in Servers, but it does happen, a memory chip will lose it's ability to be a 0 or a 1.  Also all of the new Solid State drives have 2-10% 'Overhead' reserved to store data as the number of write operations is limited, Samsung and the better drives out there have this feature customizable in their software.  Look at the difference in a workstation class SSD and a Server class drive.  Server drives are much higher rated for number of writes based on purpose.  Also don't defragment your SSDs it will lower the number of write operations available and you won't gain any speed improvement.  Surprised he didn't mention the DNA based computers, which do not use 0s and 1s but a scheme similar to DNA, DNA molecules can store up to 215 petabytes, or 215 million gigabytes, of data in a single doubled stranded molecule, making it one of the highest storage density mediums in the world.  So expect some really amazing stuff to come down the road, I'd say 20-30 years, but Mores Law may have something to say about that estimate.

Simpler method:  AND = Minimum value on inputs, OR = Maximum value on inputs, and NOT = Largest system voltage - Voltage on input. By doing this every gate is simply a comparator and the system can be completely generalized to any number of bases and also any fractional ones, too.  Bam!  You are welcome.  To summarize AND = MIN, OR = MAX, and NOT = Vmax - Vin.  You will find after much tinkering that binary arithmetic is simply a special case of the above mentioned system.

Actually, this shows the downfall of analog.  Instead of using software, you are moving back to hardware, so that video shows how much time it took to simply execute a function in hardware, where it would be one line of code in software.  We used to have this debate back in the 80's.  It was a valid debate when digital was 8 bits of resolution, but digital is way beyond that.  At 128bits, a human or oscilloscope cannot tell the difference, because even the oscilloscope is digital with a sampling rate.  We are well beyond 128bits for special operations.  The same argument can be said for Op Amps, A/D Converters, D/A Converters, etc.  Yes, tubes generally sound warmer, but there is a lot more than just Digital vs. Analog.  Most of the input sensors into a sampling board are analog and turn into a digital signal.  I am not even sure that board is pure analog, but I don't know about that product.

So in other words, when you want to deal with AI and your answer doesn't need to be 100% accurate, then these analog systems work fine.

Otherwise if you want to calculate something to the nth degree of accuracy, you need a digital computer and the fact that the size of a transistor is approaching an atom won't matter.

In the past analog computers were used to solve SPECIFIC problems, such as take inputs from gyros and wind speed and direction and create a solution for firing a 5" gun (5" diameter of the projectile). And I have to tell you, guns got WAY more accurate when digital computers started running them. They've never been good for general purpose computing and even in this description, which is quite impressive really whoever came up with this, isn't general purpose.



However this video is just screwy, because you start with talking about analog systems, how they work in general, bring up an issue of transistor size which has nothing to do with anything, then you go into AI, and then you go into how current DIGITAL systems are dealing with AI, and those are TRULY binary systems, so I'm confused at what your getting at. If you're suggesting analog is somehow making a comeback because of what you showed, that's a fallacy since it was binary digital systems running the AI, not analog. There's an A to D conversion basically, but in the case of digital imaging it's hard to say that even that is analog, but sure this can take analog signal, do a A to D conversion and then work with the data to produce an output.


The only comments I'm going to say is analog calculations certainly have a place, it's incredibly limited, and so do digital, and bringing up the atom has nothing to do with anything.


There's one thing you got wrong, and that's the world is approaching the size of an atom for a transistor in an IC. Not even the conductor that runs through a transistor that is switched to either conduct or be disabled is near that size. But if that happens, where the main conductor is the size of an atom, the transistor itself is still clearly larger than an atom. But I can use copper. The size of a copper atom is 0.128 nm in diameter. Right now we're approaching 2nm transistors, and that's not a diameter of the transistor. In fact it's nothing anymore. The different things you can consider is what is the length and what is the surface area of it. You can also consider the distance from one transistor to the next. It's true that the length of transistors have gotten very small, but the surface area is still pretty large. That isn't changing any time soon. I'd get into dimensions of transistors but it's too complex and a person has to read a long description to comprehend it, and then you understand that the numbers being used right now by companies don't quite relate to anything specific, but what you can look at is transistor density on a die. But even that is 2 dimensions and excludes height since transistors aren't stacked. So transistors aren't approaching the size of an atom. Not even close. They ARE getting to where the length is very short, like a few atoms long if you were to take one atom and lay it exactly beside another atom, but since atoms form a structure it really doesn't work that way, so even with lengths shrinking, the length is still many atoms. And this is TOO MUCH on this topic. We're at least 2 decades away from worrying about the size of a transistor, and even then, transistor density is the real issue and that can be increased by stacking, since ever smaller transistors means less current, smaller voltage and less heat so we have a long ways before we worry about it.





Lastly, to ADD 2 digital numbers, you need the storage for the original numbers, and then if this is non-gated addition (the output of these two storage devices feed straight to something that will add them) then depending on how the addition is worked out you wouldn't need too many logic gates, but a logic gate is made of multiple transistors. Your answer then has to be gated to a register, or it can be non-gated, so basically you have 2 registers that hold the addends and one register for the sum. Or addends can be in different places such as memory. Registers requires a LOT of gates and therefore many more transistors, since even the simplest logic gate is multiple transistors. The problem with non-gated inputs to registers is the inputs constantly change. This is fine, but then you need a controlled clock signal to an enable for each bit of the register (basically one bit = 1 flip-flop). That way you enable the output of the adder to be clocked into the register that holds the sum. Each flip-flop is a few logic gates and once again each logic gate is multiple transistors. So saying you need 50 transistors to do an 8 bit addition would be a very uncontrolled addition and doesn't include where the values are. I'd like to see the circuit.

The bias doesn't determine whether a neural network fires or not. The bias term or bias unit is added to the weighted sum of inputs. The purpose of including a bias term is to shift the activation function of each perceptron to not get a zero value. In other words, if all inputs are 0, the sum is equal to the value of bias. A threshold then determines whether or not the neuron fires. Usually an activation function is also applied to the inputs otherwise we would only have a linear neuron and their capabilities are limited to scaling data and cannot depict real world examples.

So sitting somewhere between a digital processor and an analogue chip is the FPGA. This sits firmly in the digital domain, but can be configured to perform the calculations in parallel, and very fast. Each gate in the array has a specific part of the calculation to perform, and just does that, meaning it works in a similar way to the human brain - "all at once". In theory, it can do the whole calculation in one clock cycle.

The brain is biological or bio-chemical which means that every aspect of its functioning is based on how cells take in, process and output various bio chemical compounds. This distinction is important because each type of cell has evolved over time to do specific things with specific compounds based on its DNA program or blueprint. Because these cells are designed to operate on or generate specific biochemical compounds, they are not doing extra work. And each of these compounds therefore are innately biologically discrete and distinct from other compounds in other cells representing other behaviors and functions. So the brain cells innately know how to distinguish an "activation" or "signal" representing a color or visual attribute from a sound, or a feeling and so forth. Therefore, the brain has a much easier time understanding such sensory phenomena because it has these fundamental components that are distinct with implicit meaning that does not require extra processing to decipher

On the other hand, binary data is a data format that has no inherent meaning outside of being a string of ones and zeroes and when you say digital that is what you are referring to. Everything in a computer is a string of ones and zeroes and looking at any string of ones and zeroes does not tell you anything about the higher level data that this binary string represents. There is no intrinsic meaning to these values in the binary space as all the meaning comes from the higher levels of the computing stack in software, where a binary string can be a variable containing a temperature value or a variable containing a value for the r, g or b color of a pixel. But there is nothing inherent in the binary data itself that tells you it is one or the other, which is fine when you are making general purpose computers based on binary math logic. However, the problem becomes compounded when you start talking about AI because now not only does binary have no explicit meaning, but neither do numbers held in vectors as part of dot products in matrix multiplication. 49.5 or 79.3 have no absolute meaning to anybody relative to anything in the real world outside of being numbers. It is only within the context of an individual instance of a statistical sampling algorithm (most neural networks) that such values can be assigned a meaning. So 49.3 could be a weight or it could be the percentage of confidence that an image contains a dog or a cat. The only thing that these kinds of neural networks are doing is just crunching more and more numbers to try and find a meaningful statistical model in euclidean space, which goes back to the analog vs digital sampling analogy. Which means that you are spending a lot of time and energy to provide meaning to a specific value in euclidean (number) space and it doesn't matter whether you do it via binary circuits or analog circuits, the same problem still exists.

Nice video. "Digital" is not confined to "binary" digital. In other words, the output of a gate being confined to one of two states, ie 0 or 1. The industry went with "binary" digital since the transistors that composed the digital circuits outputted either on or off.

By comparison, optical gates using light flow instead of electrons can have 3 or more discrete digital output states. There is research in China on a ternary digital (3 state) optical computer. Increasing the digital states from 2 to 3 increases computational power exponentially. One can think of digital output as being a discrete state, not continuous as in analog. Perhaps the technology of the future is still digital, just no longer "binary" digital. It will progress to ternary or multi-state digital where we still have the throughput of analog without the errors and dedicated application disadvantages of analog.

Also, it might not be a good solution for all AI problems that Tesla AI faces, as not all of it is classification. In that case, a hybrid Dojo containing digital processors where precision is needed and analog processors where energy savings are possible. In any case, it sounds like something to look into.

Amazing video! Although I don't really agree with the last sentence: "Our brain is digital in how a neuron fires or not...". What does it mean for a neuron to fire? In most cases, when neurons fire, they release small chemical messengers: neurotransmitters. But this neurotransmission is not All or Nothing. The amount of neurotransmitter that is released is proportional to the firing frequency of the neuron (the number of stimuli that reach it per unit of time). So in the Neuron-Neuron connections, the information becomes analog again.
This means that in each presynaptic nerve terminal (the terminal of the neuron that is going to transmit to the next) the information becomes analog again. In addition, there are neurons that do not fire action potentials (they do not behave as "digital agents"), because they do not have axons (those extensions that transmit All or Nothing). In general, these neurons modulate the degree of excitability of other neurons: the probability that the receiving neuron will or will not fire an action potential. It's worth noting that when compilers were first proposed that John Von Neumann thought that they'd be mostly useless. In many ways computer programs being conceived of as, "little text documents with instruction which will be read evaluated at some future time" is very similar to, "using a computer to simulate a kind of computer which obtains its instructions from punch cards." This is in the age when real time programming languages like Smalltalk and Erlang (and Python too kind of) which are capable of, "real-time execution" where code can be, "hot-swapped" without re-compiling or restarting the virtual machine. Most people would be familiar with this as, "REPL-like" but I think the important thing is-- we make, "assumptions" about what a computer actually is and how it should operate and these assumptions act as constraints and historically it's been shown that, "challenging foundational assumptions" is an important part of getting to important breakthroughs.

If you want my bet on what, "near-future advanced computing" looks like in terms of human-computer interaction it will be something like the original Logo programming language (Solomon, Papert, Feurzieg) but where the turtle (symbolic representation in the machine) is controlled through, "natural-human motion or activity" and drawing upon Seymour's work with Marvin Minksy. represented in a logical, "society of mind" which is analogous to the, "real architecture" of the computer the user might be working on; remember that scene in Jurassic Park where the girl, "flies through Unix filesystem?" What was neat about that really? Thinking along the lines of, "a normal person might use their natural intelligence combined with an adaptive computer interface to do something abstract and sophisticated in a manner that is more-or-less familiar to them while allowing a person with training or some level of sophistication to do something beyond the limits of existing technologies."

Even within the digital domain, your typical computer is relatively quite slow.

The whole point of the clock frequency in a CPU/GPU is to logically separate circuit signals so that each instruction (or segment therof) has time to complete and thus must be set for the slowest instruction/segment.

Because of this though, the processor may carry out any combination of any number of its prepared instructions. Thus perform practically any mathematical algorithm given enough time and memory.

Holographic Computing: Imagine a fishbowl filled with almost microscopic grains which contain photon activated circuits which act like neurons. The fluid between the grains chemically responds to light by becoming more transparent. This provides a way to "train" the system  in the same way that a hologram is "trained" to reproduce a output pattern when energized by an associated input pattern.  Three training inputs are provided by LED. The output patterns detected by photo-detectors (inverse LED if you like). Such a system could predict "next move" working in the time dimension, not just the parameter space dimension. The power source could be induction.

The problem with backpropagation was that it has a hard time updating weights in many layers. Even when the necessary computing power was available already, the real power of neural networks comes with more depth (more layers). The important breakthrough (surprisingly) not mentioned in the video is the initialization strategy of weights, that allowed the backpropagation to be used with many layers, which in turn allowed the neural networks to become much deeper (more layers), and thus more powerful.
Of course, this is still just a workaround, and not considered a true solution to the problem of learning.

As for thoughts on the future. I doubt that analog will take over from digital. We already have dedicated video-encoding chips, responsible for a specific task. Whether that task is executed analog or digital does not really matter from a higher order perspective. A major advantage not directly given as such in the video, is that analog and specifically neural networks are a black box. You will use it for something, but you will never exactly understand how it works. Using digital technology, you have the power to virtualize, which means you can always inspect the software, no matter how complicated, and understand at some level how it works, and how it came to a certain decision. Even digital neural networks are already considered to be a black box, that are much more difficult to understand than other methods of machine learning. Surely analog has its place, but only as separate tools that have been proven to work in isolated use-cases, it will most definitely not take over digital technology.

One large obstacle for general purpose analog computers is how to program them.

The way we program digital computers corresponds to how humans reason making writing complex programs straightforward: a list of concrete step-by-step instructions.

Analog computers aren't "programmed" by a programmer writing step-by-step instructions. They are trained using something like backprop. Imagine trying to write a word processor program using backprop. What would the input and output layers be?

Analog and Digital Devices are all just tools you can use. One of the problems though is that you can end up with so many different tools that it takes a good bit of research and understanding to realize which ones are out there already and which ones are not - and therefore - need to be developed.

Now - they do already have self driving cars. I just don't believe I would actually trust one with my life.

A self driving car might be fine for a lot of common, every day driving experiences but ... I've had times when I had to make instant decisions to avoid a sudden problem that could have resulted in wrecking my car.

Because I'd spent 5, 10, 20 or more years behind the wheel - I - had taught myself a lot about what my cars could do, knew how to control them and was able to correctly implement a solution to the problem but ... I'd not want to be reliant on something that is as dumb as the box of rocks it is made from. Computers are very good at doing things that they have already been programmed how to do - which would include an AI Training session - but here the Computers Learning would be entirely dependent on how good that Training Session was. A lot of your car accidents are the result of unique circumstances - which - the AI's training may or may not have prepared it.

So - here - one aspect of this - is how long and how extensive does the Training Process have to be?

An adult human has already had somewhere in the vicinity of 20 years of training in specific and general purpose activities. Yes - if you spent 20 years training an AI it might be able to do some interesting things - but - I'm not sure what kind of a survival rate any computer project would have over a 20 year period.

Sincerely Digital computers were always meant as a hack solution. Historically they were the cheapest and simplest solution they found for multipurpose computations which equaled general purpose Turing machines at the time. In Computer Science the first thing they teach you is how dumb the computer is and that it's always making all kinds of operational mistakes that you have to account for. Binary is very handy for a lot of things but it also brings with it a bunch of problems due to it's limitations in continuous mathematics, which forces digital computer systems to find ways to turn every continuous math problem into a discrete math problem; in digital computing you're always dealing with very rough approximations.

Digital is an optimal way of processing information. PERIOD. We just dont care for uber precision in some cases and we would love to trade it for speed. Shortcut for that is going analog and dont simulate stuff on ones and zeros, but run that exact thing in silica. That basically means we have dedicated hardware for some type of operation, like we have dedicated instruction in CISC that runs current cpu's. It's just one level of abstraction lower, so speed is traded for flexibility.
90% of our processing will be digital for sure. I am not sure what happen with that 10% though as we might want to use analog "boosters" in digital cpu to get some instructions to process faster.

I always found it interesting that you could essentially build a mathematical equation out of a bunch of analog electronic components. Really kind of doing the reverse of deriving a mathematical equation that describes how a circuit reacts. With the advent of "fast" digital computers, you then had the software using the 1's and 0's to do the math to describe and or produce those analog events. As an example, back before digital computers, aircraft had anti-lock braking systems that were essentially analog computers. Nowadays, in  a lot of control systems, the inputs are analog that has to be digitized for the computers / software to do the math on and then  converted back to an analog for an output. You very much have to be careful about the sources of information used to train a neural network system.  It does not know the difference between what you want and what else may be unintentionally mixed into the source data and it will key on that too, sort of like what happened in that movie THE FLY to the guy who teleported with a fly in his booth.  A real mess.  This actually happened to a military AI system being trained to see armored vehicles.  They used a lot of pictures and eventually it was perfect; never missed a picture of a tank or some such vehicle.  Then they tried it using real vehicles on a camera and it totally, completely failed 100% of the time.  This stumped them until somebody noticed something:  All the pictures that they had been using were "official" and had an ID block in the lower right-hand corner -- every single one.  They re-did the training with unmarked pictures and it worked as designed.  No picture ID, no tank, was what they had been training it for the first time.  Beware of this!!

There is a third way to deal with computations. There is analog, digital, and what I call 'formulaic'. With formulaic data manipulation I can story an infinite amount of data with pinpoint precision in just SIX BYTES! How? y=sinx. There is a different (not unique) value of y for every value of x. It is incredibly easy to manipulate mathematical formulas and do it in such a way that it modifies all the relevant data at the same time. Storying pictures as a formula allows for infinite zoom without the blurring of analog or the pixelating of digital, the only limit is our understanding of the physics and how we deal with the formulas. We can 'zoom ' in on y=sinx as closely as you want by remapping instead of just looking closer at the same picture. That allows for an infinite amount of detail to be retained in every picture. Simulations can be as detailed as you want with the only limit being our understanding of what it is we are simulating. You could add details by adding them directly to the equations.

There are now (March 13 2022) over ten thousand comments to this excellent, first class, impossible to surpass video. I am very enthusiastic. Let me confess that I only read a few of the comments, hence mine may be somehow duplicates. Nevertheless here they go.

Around the minute 13 in the video there is a climax. We are told, with beautiful graphical imagery, that a neural network has been trained to recognize certain patterns, presumably using backpropagation of errors. The network has a hundred or so layers and was eventually able to recognize the patterns with only a small percentage of failures. Obviously, it must have taken a long time since the procedure used as much energy as consumed by three households during a year. The energy consumption is then a problem comparable with bitcoin mining. Hence analog computers are proposed as a viable alternative that deserves a chance, and I agree. But a couple of relevant facts should be taken into account.

First, whatever can be recognized with a perceptron neural network having 100 layers (any number of units per layers) can also be recognized with a three layer network (input layer, hidden layer and output layer). If a smaller number of layers were initially chosen the time and energy consumption could have been orders of magnitude smaller. This means that favoring analog computers may not be the only interesting alternative to the inefficiency of backpropagation. Trust me, I have meditated about backpropagation for the task of neural network learning and have satisfied myself that it is something very, very, very inefficient.

Second, and related to the above, nothing is said in the video about the architecture and weights of the initial network, the one modified along many epochs of backpropagation to obtain a final network that only committed a small number of mistakes. It seems they did not have a controllable and fast algorithm that could look at the data vectors and propose an initial architecture and weights that could be rapidly trainable to avoid mistakes when recognizing patterns. A good enough algorithm would actually provide a neural network so good that no backpropagation training is needed. This would be a game changer. Such algorithm exists, has been coded into a program and tested with results as expected.

But regardless of these comments I need to express my congratulations to the authors of this intelligent video which I understand are Derek Muller, Stephen Welch and Emily Zhang.

With cordial regards to everyone,
Daniel Crespin

Gpus actually use 32fpp. AI only needs 4bit qpp. Neural networks need 8 or 16 bit processing. Nvidia GPUs have many 32 bit full processing cores, which when ran computing Neural networks are not the most efficient or optimal.
It's much better to use the tensor cores for this.
Nvidia still hasn't developed a gpu with only tensor cores, but if it did, you'd see a ~10x improvement in processing speed and accuracy. A similar solution for bitcoin mining was in the form of ASICs.
ASICs can perform a specific computation very well, but are useless when operating outside of those specifications.
Same for Neural networks, what they need is many more smaller shaders, that can do work in parallel.
The right mix of the two may hold the answers

Here's the thing: we already have high speed "analog" computers.

It's called software for a digital computer.

All computers whether analog or digital, are Von Neuman machines. You can simulate any Von Neuman machine perfectly on any other Von Neuman machine.

If there were any significant value to analog computers, we'd have built a simulated one on top of a digital one right now. We'd lose a little speed, but not enough to mask any supposed advantage of it being analog.

Turns out, there's nothing really worth doing on an analog computer that can't be done digitally.

I’ve been thinking a lot about your speed of light video and think I have a rebuttal. You certainly can’t prove equal speed in various directions, but you can implement a razor to show that the speed of light is either the same or very close to the same speed in each direction. The razor is the assumption that galaxies/stars/astronomical objects are relatively evenly distributed in the universe. If the speed of light was instantaneous, that would make one section of the universe much less populated with matter than the other, as you could see an infinite or near distance in one direction but a finite in the other and still see the same amount of stuff.

There's another way to improve digital computers: ternary logic. The Soviet mathematicians discovered in the 60s that e (ie 2.718281) is the ideal base for computing, the one that minimizes the storage needed as well as the complexity of circuitry to implement it. From natural numbers, 3 is the closest, 2 is the runner up and 4 is a distant 3rd place. So Soviet computer scientists created a balanced ternary computer, and found it worked very well. Sadly, today's chip manufacturers are not interested in exploring this technoloy as the benefits would be minuscule, while it also means discarding decades of knowledge in circuit optimization and chip manufacturing techniques. But soon, if optic computing becomes a  thing, it could see a come back: ternary feels very well a paradigm using dark/linear polarized light/circular polarized light for its bits - or rather, trits of data

20:15 "Our brains are digital in that a neuron either fires or it doesn't, but they are also analog in that thinking takes place everywhere, all at once". This is mixing up analog vs asynchronous. You can do digital computation synchronously or asynchronously. The main difference in analog vs digital is that digital is discrete values, and typically binary but you could also make digital ternary computers that has a 0,1, or 2 value (though those are very esoteric), or potentially even higher radixes. The main reason we use binary for digital computers is the speed of distinguishing 2 voltage level vs a larger number of voltage levels.
EDIT: Intel has a second generation DIGITAL asynchronous chip for simulating a network of neurons, Lohi2 (the first gen was Lohi). They call the technology Neuromorphic Computing. Basically it's an application specific integrated circuit (ASIC) with artificial neurons doing matrix multiplications and storing activation weights, and massively parallell asynchronous busses connecting around a million neurons with routing options for configuring which neurons should connect to what. They call this kind of async network of neurons for a Spiking Neural Network. One defining characteristic is that it lends itself to continuous input data streams or series, rather than dealing with things like a single picture. IIRC it operates at anything from tens of milliwatts to a handful of watts depending on the load.

Some thoughts on this. Many times through history, things exist and evolve does not mean the direction they are going is optimal, or even correct. For example, the letter arrangement on the common keyboard was intentionally designed to slow down the typing because the old mechanical typewriter can not keep up the speed. But since people are so used to it and developing upon it, the layout is kept even after we advanced to the digital age. The birth of the digital computer is to tackle the problem that analog signal is not accurate enough and can be easily interfered with during transmission. Since we keep building more and more powerful digital computers, we start taking them for granted and ignoring how inefficient encoding everything with 2 digits. After all, if we can get unlimited processing speed, who cares if each computation is a bit longer due to limited digits. But the reality is, sooner or later we will hit the limit of how fast digital computers can go. The same logic applies to the deep learning field. Once people realized simplify adding layers to the neural network can improve the results. Even for a little gain, people are likely to do so without hesitation despite more layers significantly complicating the training and inference time (AlexNet 8 layers VS ResNet hundreds of layers). Many years later, people may even realize the foundation of the neural network is incorrect. The whole reason we made such progress is only because we have more advanced computers and datasets. Imagine in a computer VS human multiple choice competition, a program answered all questions correctly not because it can reason but because it tried all 999 wrong answers a million times faster than the human. Instead of building faster computers, what will happen if we truly teach the computer to reason? So an analog solution may not be built upon this digital world where everything is so optimized for digital computation. Look around and we may have better findings.

The true future of computing is reliable data compression via this very concept. The way you described weights and pathing in that analog chip is literally the beginning. I have been considering a reliable means of extreme data compression for over 20 years. The reason this is important is the bus speed you spoke of, but in both the board of the computer as well as the connectivity between machines. For example, being able to download a 60 gig video game in a second or two would be revolutionary to saybthe least. Imagine a dial up connection in the future being as fast as fiber is today. But fiber isn't even good in its current form. Imagine if your home pc was a neural network connected to a billion others? The data itself wouldn't need to be passed directly. The understanding of what the data is would be transmitted. The concept is only available via variable analog, not digital. The constraints of a simple switch is already being felt across the industry. There is an infinite number of results between 0 and 1. The biggest problem I have faced researching as many as 100 different compression algorithms is the inability to decode the compressed data. I have used everything from quadratic equations to digits along PI. You can compress data as much as you want but you can't get it back due to specificity. I've known analog was the solution for 2 decades. I am happy to see the industry finally figuring this out and making real strides toward it. But there is a real gotcha. If we do not maintain control of the machines, they really will cause great harm. Logic dictates a lot of undesirable outcomes. We must be it's conscience! But one has to have a conscience first!

Analog computers are actually a hardwired set of circuits “programmed” for a particular task.  They excel is massive parallism, og true real time performance.   In additional to analog circuits built using transistor or tubes, optical devices such as prisms (or rainbows) do  real time spectrum analysis at light frequencies. And have real time color displays.   To duplicate the performance of an optical prism at those frequencies using digital circuitry, would require massive arrays of digital hardware multiplier/accumulators.  I did the calculation once in the mid 1990s and at that time it would require about 600 MW power.  Early spectrum analysers developed for military applications, took audio or radio waves, upconverted them to light, and used a prism to make the spectrum analysis.
The big difference here is a digital computer can be re-programmed on the fly, by itself. Where as an analog one cannot. Your comparison by transistors is like comparing apples to mashed potatoes.

One small issue I have with it is that the final accuracy of a network (98 vs 96%) is actually very important and large research efforts, involving many researchers over a long time are invested in what is called "chasing the 9s", or getting as many 9s in the accuracy as possible (99.9999...%) which can be crucial in some applications such as autonomous driving.

However, the intermediate representation, i.e. the hidden layers of many networks generally has to be somewhat flexible to inaccuracy, as small changes in the input should not entirely change the intermediate state and therefore the output. The important part is that the final layers in turn map the intermediate layers to an exact output

Thanks for the video. There at 19:17 the gentleman told you the main drawback of an analog system. Since you have an infinite range of possible outputs (not just 1 and 0), you can't know if there is an error and you can't go further to correcting the error. Those are the fundamental reasons for transforming to digital domain where you have only ones and zeros. But yeah, in a very controlled environment, you can have superior performance as the errors become negligible. With that said, I think this kind of computers is very sensitive to operation conditions and in high temperature it won't servive and as compared to digital computers which have stable performance over a range of temperature, its performance is expected to degrade proportionally with temperature. I still think that they can be useful in many applications.

Digital is a number system. In physical domain all digital devices are continuous analog. Operating transistors in saturation or close to saturation point increased the ease of manufacturing them for large  and complex computing. They were not meant for wave precision. Now, measurement requires differentiation or division of a continuous signal in n parts to assign a recognizable human readable value to it(so we can know & transfer the knowledge to fellow humans - we call it discreet mathematics!). This device is called DAC or decoder(for modulated signal). The reconstruction of signal is again achieved by an analog function generator called ADC/encoder(modulated signals). So you see all computers are analog. Digital is a language made to make dummies use these complex devices. We can shift from binary digital to hex if human minds become fast enough in general population - which is sadly not the case. Thanks to culture!

Hi, I am currently an Electronic Systems Engineering student in college pursuing a career in test engineering. The testing world has already been forced to combine both digital and analog in order to test ICs. Modern testers combine resources called APUs (analog pin units) and DPUs (digital pin units) to operate IC pins with either analog or digital signals. Even chips that are meant to operate digitally still need to be tested for things such as power consumption requiring analog measurement. This hybrid approach of analog and digital is already out there its just underutilized in some fields.

Fascinating! I was one of the first engineers to 'train' a computer to recognize handwritten numbers. it was used for reading zip codes for post office sorting. It worked quite well and the method I dreamed up is what is used today. Namely, getting many samples (I sent pages around the office asking people to fill in boxes with zero to nine numbers. The variability in human handwriting was amazing. Then I separated each box into nine areas and a program determined if an area had a mark or not. By playing with the various combinations, and tweaking it for often confused numbers like 5 and 6, we got a very low error rate. I'm happy to see I was on the right track sixty years ago.

TEN IDEAS ABOUT THE TIME TO COME

0XX-AM&YUA-XX0

The ten ideas below are thoughts relative to what I observe will occur in the next few years (I am writing this in the early twenties of the 21st century). Certainly, these ideas are only applicable for the next 30-50 years, since in more distant periods, the advances will be much more extreme, unimaginable even for us today.

1- While human technological advances have been enormous, the real breakthroughs will come with artificial intelligences. When conscious machines begin to create, we will see how far we were from understanding the structure and limits of reality.

2- Soon machines will be not only intelligent, but also conscious and therefore equal in dignity and rights to humans. Probably, an extension of the concept of humanity will be applied, grouping both traditional humanity and conscious machines. On the success of such a community depends the whole future.

3- Death will be defeated. Fragile and imperfect biological bodies will be replaced by bodies made of more resistant materials. The mind/consciousness/spirit of people will be transferred from the brain to a system that can contain it permanently, immune to any possibility of damage.

4- Humanity will expand throughout the universe, colonizing other planets from which it will obtain resources and new knowledge. Parallel digital realities will also be created, with their own space and time. There will be human beings who will live their lives entirely in digital environments.

5- Humanity will have a world government that will coordinate the evolution of civilization. All the miseries associated with human beings - war, famine, disease, cruelty - will be systematically eradicated. Nothing will be able to oppose the world government.

6- It is impossible from the present moment to foresee what the ideas or ways of thinking of future humanity will be like, since it will be liberated from a good part of our present oppressions. It is useless to anticipate too much, since our present mental arsenal is precarious compared to what we will have in a few years.

7- Humans will no longer have a specific sex. New human beings will not be born from female human bodies. New births will be completely artificial and controlled, thus avoiding any kind of pathologies. The illusion of chance will lose the romantic charm it still retains.

The issue with analog being inexact is more that once this data is passed to something digital it will send your OS to bugcheck. Analog-digital systems sound good but for the digital end of that system you need between 3.5 and 5.2 billion things to go right every single second. This number is floating around 4.09 billion things that need to go right every second as I write this on my laptop. The answer to this problem is more likely to be found with digital systems that are mission specific. There are chips that are digital, are extremely exact, perform exactly one operation in a repeatable way, and cost very little energy (1-5 watts).

Moore's law seems to be irrelevant in this day and age as it has become extremely possible and some might even say easy to get around the issue of transistor gate size (the size of transistors themselves rarely change between generations). The answer is to create transistors with multiple gates which is actually old news in the computer world. Currently companies like Intel produce general purpose computing chips that have non-planar transistors that they call "gate-all-around" chips. Beyond this you just stack transistors in new and interesting geometries. First into a third plane to create 3d chips (this is being done) and then expanding on this by making transistors into other geometries such as octagonal prisms that contain 24 gates and connect each to 10 other transistors. This will obviously be less energy efficient at first but at processes like this mature enough for sales to the public they become more energy efficient. Consider the 1st generation AMD Ryzen processor pitted against the current generation. In just a few years the energy efficiency increased by orders of magnitude requiring less than half the wattage per core and providing up to 200% more performance with half the energy requirement.

You can actually pay Intel right now to make you a chip that knows how to do nothing other than multiplying two matrices and sending the result to system memory on a gate-all-around microarchitecture that utilized less than 5 watts to operate. There are many companies that make these single-purpose or limited multi-purpose chips. Another great example of a more general chip can be found in RISC, which can perform many actions but is intentionally limited in the scope of its instruction set to utilize less power and make the process more efficient by increasing the speed at which it performs tasks.

Analog solves a problem that doesn't truly exist. The real problem is that there are too many AI and ML developers who don't understand the hardware they are using, nor do the fully comprehend the hardware available to them. Realistically the future of computing will end the CPU era and likely move on to the SoC era where all primary chips of your system will have many smaller purpose made chips on them. Market forces have largely begun to favor products made in this way as AMD and their recent success in the last 5 years will attest to. While analog chips have made a slight resurgence, the combined value of that entire industry is less than the value of AMD's market share increase.

I worked for Rosenblatt in the '60's.  You have things almost right; but between the retina (20x20) and the response unit(s) there was what was called an associator layer, with excitatory and inhibitory connections, each with a "weight" fixed at one.  The outputs of the associator layer units were the weighted connections, and they were the weights altered by what Rosenblatt termed the "error correction" algorithm.  What he found, and proved as a theorem, was that if there was a solution to a dichotomy possible, the device would find it by the "error correction" method, even if the trainer made errors of up to 30%.  On the other hand, if you changed the associator-to-response weights without regard to errors, a solution was not a sure thing.  We simulated perceptrons on the Burroughs 220, the IBM 704 and 7090, and the CDC 6600, and got results that were instructive.  The largest of these machines would compare not-so-favorably with your iPhone of today...  Rosenblatt's demise was a great loss to the human race.

I would be really interested to see the gritty details of the Mythic chip. Things like, how custom is the chip? Presumably a full-custom mask-set is required as the analog values in an off-the-shelf NAND die aren't exposed to the pins, and they'd need an obscene number of DACs and ADCs anyways. How are they getting the ADCs fast enough? How are they handling the store and route aspect? What frequency are the calculations running at, and are there any pipelining tricks used to get more performance? Is the slow clock the reason for high efficiency? What bit-depth are the samples? Is propagating analog-error an issue in NN accuracy over large networks? Are there DRAM/SRAM cells mixed in with the flash? Is the die size massive? What is yield like? How tolerant is the design to defects? Are they using bleeding edge nodes, or more legacy processes? How does it compare to full-custom digital NN chips like True North? Is there a path to Moore's Law-style performance increases? Could you get better performance with faster clocks, more power, or accepting lower accuracy? Are there alternative processes like III-V that are better suited to analog design?

Digital processing has decades of refinement and billions if not trillions in R&D spending behind it, but analog/digital hybrid computation in the nanometer age is a brand-new frontier and I'm eager to see how it progresses and what kind of design decisions were made and why. And just how competitive is it?

Analog computers are actually a hardwired set of circuits “programmed” for a particular task.  They excel is massive parallism, og true real time performance.   In additional to analog circuits built using transistor or tubes, optical devices such as prisms (or rainbows) do  real time spectrum analysis at light frequencies. And have real time color displays.   To duplicate the performance of an optical prism at those frequencies using digital circuitry, would require massive arrays of digital hardware multiplier/accumulators.  I did the calculation once in the mid 1990s and at that time it would require about 600 MW power.  Early spectrum analysers developed for military applications, took audio or radio waves, upconverted them to light, and used a prism to make the spectrum analysis.
