Well, I really like Veritasium contents, especially because it very often offers extra glimpes on something we /think/ we knew, but actually did not think about from /that/ view angle.

This is one of the times in which I know something of the described topic, but as I graduated with a work in which I needed to teach a neural network to do some math, in 1994, I think I know something more than my usual on this ground :).

A few remarks, then, very likely subject to some lack of precision, as I am going back in my memory by about thirty years, I do apologize in advance for this:

1. The limit of Rosenblatt's perceptron was not in the lack of depth; it was in the utilized activation function of the neurons model. This was the essential contribution of Minsky and Papert's cited paper, that showed how, in spite of its layering depth, no perceptron could have solved the rather well known, and extremely simple problem of xor recognition; this destroyed the confidence in the approach. For a few decades.

The element that changed the whole picture was the introduction of continuous activation function of a peculiar shape (and with further mathematical peculiarities), tipically named sigmoid (due to their S shape), that allowed Robert Hecht-Nielsen to formulate his continuity representation /existential/ theorem, stating that for any continuous function of n variables there is a three layer sigmoidal-activation-function-unit network that can compute it. The matter was that being just an existential theorem, it did not tell how wide the layer should have been, and various practical experiments showed that a more-than-three layers network could learn more easily than a three layers one. Things were working fine sometimes and not as much some others. This is told in the video, and I'll have to get better information on the cited paper of Fei Fei Li to combine its content with my old memories, but for years lots of trials were made, and papers written to get where we are today. A very interesting MOOC kept by Andrew Ng (Stanford) tells way more about overfitting, and various other issues you will have to address when teaching a network.

2. Rather than from early failures of neural networks, AI winter came more from the fail of so called fifth-generation languages hype, or what at the time was named, in an old-fashion parlance, Hard-AI, that is, the belief the a with an inferential engine and a good knowledge base any problem could be solved through the application of deduction and induction steps. Actually the re-sprouting of artificial neural network in the late 80s gave a shake revamping interest and hopes in what was then called Soft-AI, or connection-based AI, where less about the reasoning, and more about the mapping was put into action.

3. Significant advances in specific achievement of "intelligent" manifestations were obtained through the speedup of computation power, but more than that, from the development of more sophisticated computational models for neurons and their interconnections (recurrent, convolutional, LSTM, etc.) that appeared to be far better suited to the solution of specific recognition problems (continuous speech, rotation-independent image-recognition, and so on); for many of them the utilization of analog computers may help, but the true essential ingredient, analog or digital, is the usage of massive parallelism, what was once called a MIMD architecture, that indeed is today reflected in GPUs, as well as in other highly parallelized computation systems.

4. For decades it has been known that the Parallel Distributed Processing was an essential ingredient (as our brain inspired from the moment we started understanding a tiny fraction of how it works from the /inside/), and today we have fantastic frameworks that ease the abstraction on the underneath implementation details (tensorflow, azure, and other deep-learning/machine learning wrappers) but to get where we are today it took, still, decades, to become good at recognizing moving objects and at /somehow/ understand spoken sentences, still with a lot of actual limitations on continuous reliability and adaptations abilities in presence of knowledge field affinity, or on non-just-spoken contextual sensitivity. Decades were needed to trim models and algorithms to be good at recognizing just a very small fraction of what our brain is still far more capable of putting together, in terms of variety. Sure, the achieved results are amazing, and we can expect to automate, to some degree various decision problems (e.g.: steering, breaking and accelerating, accepting indications, suggestions, requests, all related to conducting a vehicle*), but there the best that we can do is to narrow the distance between what we can compute in a fraction of time of how it required in the past, and what we cannot really determine to be *right*, because such a *right is out of reach from a purely technical or scientific context, or worse, simply not really well known yet, as this long pandemic period has clearly recalled to all of us.

Very likely combining analog and digital components will be giving more that we have today, but as you very accurately remarked in the video, analog computers do not have the same expressive power (in terms of generality) of digital computers, and that will remain so until we'll have the ability to synthesize generic arbitrarily complex analog circuitry on the fly, a thing that I can say but have not the faintest Idea of how it could possibly ever be achieved; analog design is still today considered far more an art than digital design is :D.

To some extent this links to the other nice video of yours on the Hole in Math (built around Gödel's Incompleteness Theorem, and on undecidability) but what it really is about is the fact that whether analog or digital, the computation will always be just that, a computation; that's relevant, and we can learn to keep improving it, but it will remain just a fraction of the whole picture, in a world that still misses opportunities for collaboration in place of fights, and destruction, alas.

We're not building computers wrong, we're just learning from our mistakes, sometimes forgetting too much, something you can say only retrospectively, and here I can really say I went too far away from my starting point :D.

Digital is the optimal solution for running deterministic (i.e. repeatable) algorithms, where 1 billion executions of the same input will result in 1 billion identical outputs. Digital systems allow for verification of data by using checksums, and therefore allow you to copy a song 1 billion times without degrading the quality. However, if you do NOT need these properties - then one can exploit the implicit mathematics without our physical world, which can be used to "calculate" a result. Just as scales will always "calculate" the correct output, physical processes cannot make "errors". However, it is impossible to fully control the input, just as you therefore cannot fully control the output. On the other hand, physical processes are "executed" by the laws of physics and thus don't need energy for processing - only for encoding the input and decoding the output.

Your illustration of a convolutional neural network (CNN) at 12:22 is a bit oversimplified.

CNNs do not work like traditional neural networks, by computing matrix multiplications over all the pixels in an image, but rather by applying a filter to the input image in order to generate a new one (more specifically, multiplying each n × n grid of pixels by a n × n matrix of weights called a convolutional filter). The new image is then down-sampled (a process known as pooling) to reduce its resolution, before a new convolutional filter is applied to it.

This architecture preserves the locality of an image (close pixels are likely more related than pixels 200px apart) while taking advantage of GPUs and requiring less neurons in the hidden layers of the network. CNNs were first introduced in 1989 by Yann Le Cun... now AI researcher at Meta/Facebook.

In the first example, the analog computer isn't really doing anything special. It is simply a circuit with resistors, capacitors, and inductors that mathematically behaves identically to an oscillating mass. The thing with the AI stuff is that their operations are simple enough that they can be modeled in hardwired circuits, rather than the digital instruction based domain where values need to be fetched and stored from memory, etc. However this is nothing new. FPGAs have been around for a very long time and are basically a configurable hardwired circuit. They are mostly digital, but can interface to analog signals to provide significantly faster signal processing. The oscilloscope in the first example has one- it bridges the gap between analog and digital and allows you to see high frequency analog signals on the digital screen. I argue that we've been doing what is suggested in this video all along, but what's shown here is simply a creative new use case.

20:17 So I'm not actually clever enough to say I fully understand the whole subject and I don't know as much as you do, but I've always understood our brains as primarily analog, which the demo at 4:19 also seems to suggest (at least to me). Our senses (our inputs) are all analog and it just intuitively feels like our brains couldn't be primarily digital given how variable the inputs are each time. Of course, I know intuition is typically misleading, but I just thought this would give some context behind my motivation for writing this.

I've always believed that human brains are generally inconsistent in thought (e.g. self-contradiction) and produce varying outputs like not being able to reliably tap a finger on a desk exactly the same way five times in a row let alone twice (I can't even imagine the exact same thing twice without at least some variation). I wonder, then, if it's because our brain sends inconsistent instructions to our fingers, if it's more of something else down the line that's causing the variation (imprecise tendons?), or maybe even some other factor in the brain such as being distracted in-between taps. Maybe none of this is true. After all, it's just my anecdotal observation.

This also reminds me of something I learned early in programming where I was taught that computers were really good at doing calculations and logical operations etc. yet were bad at things humans find trivial such as facial recognition and language comprehension (like how so many of us struggle with maths yet pick up language easily while digital computers struggle with the opposite). As computers represented digital I thought it made sense to assume we were analog, though I'm worried that might be a false dichotomy. (I don't know if anything can be 100% analog, though 100% digital does seem to make sense at least ostensibly hence the reason I used "primarily analog" to describe our brains).

In short: I'm just wondering if the reason analog is more efficient for building what is essentially a brain is because using analog to build a primarily analog system is intrinsically more efficient than using digital to build a primarily analog system. We'll still have digital computers to help us do most of the things we're naturally bad at, but if we want them to be good at what we do, then looking for something that more closely resembles what we actually use such as analog does make a lot of sense. Perhaps, in future, we might even be able to design a hybrid brain that utilises both digital and analog to complement each other and eliminate the weaknesses of both.

@14:18 "Now the size of a transistor is approaching the size of an atom" That is very much not true. The size of the transistor hasn't changed for last several node sizes. Transistors have been rearranged to fit more of them in the same space, but their size hasn't changed. And they're not going to change in the next few node sizes either, they're just going to stack them up. When you read "7nm" technology that's just a marketing term, there are no 7nm features in a 7nm chip.

Also, nitpick, in your analog adder example, if you're using current to perform computation you will not be as power efficient as a digital CMOS-based adder. Not even close. CMOS-based computers barely use any current (and therefore any energy), they operate on potentials and only consume (truly) tiny amounts of energy when they switch states. Just because it has fewer components it doesn't mean it's more power efficient. Maybe cheaper, maybe.

Mostly good video (as usual), but one part really bothers me:

Human neurons do not work the way you have claimed and illustrated. This is a very common error in teaching about neural networks that I've come across several times during my BS and MS courses in computer science. (Both professors and textbooks on neural networks get this horrifically wrong.) What you describe as how human neurons work is actually only how virtual neurons in neural networks work, and it would be far more accurate to say that they were inspired by biology rather than saying they are similar to biological neurons in any significant way.


Here is how real neurons work: A neuron is a cell that contains chemicals. Neurons communicate by adding chemicals (neurotransmitters) to other neurons. Those chemicals alter the electric charge of the neuron. When the electric charge of a neuron becomes high enough (exceeds a threshold potential unique to each neuron), an action potential is generated, and the neuron fires, transferring neurotransmitters to neurons it is connected with outgoing connections.

How is this different from neural networks?

First, real neurons don't have "weights" that are analogous to neural networks. The amount of neuro-transmitter emitted is highly dependent on varying conditions. A neuron that fires rapidly can run out of a neurotransmitter, causing it to quit signaling, even when it is firing. For an example of this, take a piece of white paper, draw two small dots on the paper a centimeter or two apart. Now, stare at one, but pay attention to the other (and make sure it isn't in your blind spot). Eventually the one you are not staring at will disappear. This is because the cells in the eye that handle transmitting images to the brain are firing faster than they can replenish, have depleted themselves, and are no longer emitting neurotransmitter when they fire. The "weight" of a neuron, in this context, is dynamic, changing constantly as other neurons fire and add neurotransmitters to it, and as it fires and removes them. Further, brain chemistry, which varies significantly over time, impacts this. When synapses (the gaps the neurotransmitters have to traverse to get to the next neuron) are wider, more neurotransmitter is lost and less gets to the target. Caffeine works by reducing the width of synapses, decreasing loss and increasing the amount of neurotransmitter to reach the target. This shows that "weight" in this sense actually has very little impact on perception, otherwise Caffeine increasing the "weight" of all neurons in the brain would cause our perception to suddenly go wonky. What actually affects our perception is mainly timing, and that leads to the second major difference.

Second, neurons don't have digital state, the way that you describe (or the way that many neural network professors describe). They aren't "on or off". Firing is a fairly instantanous event, not a "state" of a neuron. Neurons don't run on a digital clock either. Calculations are happening constantly in massive parallel even far beyond what those analog chips are capable of. The calculations aren't synchronized in any way either. Neural networks aren't really similar to real biological neural systems at all. Even the level of connectedness is all wrong. Neural networks are typically constructed in layers, where each layer is fully connected to the next and the previous, with no connections to any other layer (with some limited exceptions, for example Recurrent Neural Nets connect the end layer to one or more earlier layers to provide some feedback). Biological neural networks are complex webs, that aren't even close to fully connected, and there aren't coherent layers.

Third, firing is not a function of how many connected neurons are transmitting at what "weight" at any particular time. Consider a neuron with a single incoming connection. Now, say that connection is firing at a very slow rate, and it is only providing neurotransmitter (let's assume one that increases the potential of the neuron) weakly. That neuron will still eventually fire. A neuron with a lot of connections firing rapidly may fire far more quickly, as it reaches its threshold potential more frequently, but this isn't an analog of "weight" either, because there is no fire or not fire. It's going to eventually fire. The variable in question isn't whether it is firing at any particular time, it's when and how often. Even using an analog processor for neural networks isn't anything like that.

The fact is, neural networks are only inspired by biological neural systems. They aren't actually close to biological neural systems, and the only real inspiration taken from biological neural systems is the use of many simple nodes in a highly connected network (which was ingenious but not terribly interesting). The truth is, trying to teach how biological neural systems work in a CS class or video on neural networks is pretty pointless, because if you taught it correctly, it would only serve to confuse because of how little the two have in common, and if you don't teach it correctly, you are miseducating people, which is a pretty horrible thing to do for someone who claims to be dedicated to teaching objective science correctly.


Anyhow, I'm not trying to be mean or rude, but I really like your videos, and it's painful to me that you screwed this up so badly. Might I suggest not trusting sources that are going far out of their expertise in explaining why something within it works. More often than not, I find they are wrong, because they don't actually understand the analogy and are often only pointing to it for unnecessary validation. The fact is, neural networks work, and there is no need for textbooks and professors to pretend like they understand neurobiology to validate them. The full extent of the truth is that some computer scientist, who didn't actually understand neurobiology himself, designed an AI system loosely inspired by his limited understanding of biological neural systems and was lucky enough that it actually worked. And that's all anyone needs to say. There's no need to give a whole lecture on neurobiology that is horribly, painfull wrong on nearly every level, to justify a design that has already been proven effective.

Maybe the thing that makes our brains so good is the permission to be wrong.

Some ask why "digital remains the way to go?" - while thinking we'll be moving on from our digital computers and using analog computers instead! These questions exemplify Veritasium's (Derek's) failure to clearly explain the important ideas. Derek constructed (or implied) a false dichotomy between digital and analog. He presents an object and says "this is an analog computer" which to many laypeople will obfuscate what that machine can or can't do; it's more like what most people would think of as a calculator (he tries to address this at around 3-4mins but it's weakly explained especially considering the video's title: "We're building Computers Wrong"). A lot of time is wasted on superfluous background info and the history of analog computers in a way that reinforces this false dichotomy by juxtaposing it against the digital computing revolution. I think the point of this video was supposed to be about integrating more analog into our digital systems. If so, the visit to the "analog startup" (Mythic AI) would've been great to illustrate how analog tech is relevant to our use of computers today and exactly where and why we'd use it in the future - but also where and why we would NOT. The attempt at making these distinctions is poorly done in this video. It seems like the guy at Mythic AI explaining their product has a far deeper understanding of where this is going and can sense that Derek is misunderstanding something. IMO the biggest single change Derek could have made is to replace almost every instance of "analog computers" with "analog computING."
Derek actually exposes his own misunderstandings when he explains his lifelong bias towards digital over analog; it is perhaps because of his own denigration towards, and prejudice against, analog that this seems so amazing to him. As many people in comments are pointing out, various uses of analog computing already exist. So, is it important that this tech is about to find its way into consumer electronics and no longer be restricted to specialist applications? YES! What does it mean for you though? Your still very digital phone could have an analog card/chip to help with some functions. Motion tracking could be better (and faster), as shown; and a high-end VR gamer setup might need an analog card to play multiplayer competitively. Your home security system could use analog computing in better 'understanding' what it sees and might decide not to alert you to that raccoon as it would a human. But all of it is essentially just making some things we already do faster or cheaper, sometimes ever so slightly better, but realistically nothing more. We will NOT be using "analog computers" in place of our digital ones any time soon (probably never). We will not have a proliferation of dominantly analog computers that run digital components. We will continue to have digital computers that run some analog components, but your analog card is gonna be doing more or less what a high-end sound-card does today, just not for sound - instead it'll be for some other very specific things. If you don't need one, you're likely not going to have one - as explained: GPUs remain important for the training processes (among other things). Mythic AI's flash cells are super cool, but SUPER misleading as presented here! So basically that "analog computer" at the start of the video is gonna be shrunk down to fit inside your typical ATX form-factor (or similar tower PC - still digital) without needing patch-cords or you touching it in any way; just like a GPU! Which to be fair: is AWESOME! But this video does a D- job at explaining it!
But does any of this imply we are "building computers wrong?" NO! That is, in fact, some disinformationist clickbait that primes you to be misled (whether purposefully or not). Somehow, after making the clickbait video, almost every following Veritasium video is clickbaity - something about that experience has stuck in Derek's head and cursed most of his content afterwards. Currently this video sits at 4.199mil views with only 191k likes - that's depressingly bad. Derek is no longer a science communicator; he is a technology-based entertainer.
To Derek, if you are reading this, you have some choices to make. I am 100% sure I'm not your only subscriber considering unsubbing to you. People in my family have already excised you from their science-education content on YouTube for reasons similar to those I've outlined above. If the current state of your audience matters to you: prove it - otherwise, you're gonna lose some of us. You may gain many more in our place; it might be highly profitable! IF you just want to entertain and just make the scientifically uninitiated emotionally gush over conceptual futurisms; you got it bro. But if you want to educate: this ain't it chief. [Edited for formatting.]

Its a cool idea but... mmmmm. I am extremely skeptical. I think they are quickly going to hit up against density limitations using flash cells (which can only get so small), and A/D converters. These components are extremely sensitive to noise, whereas digital components are not. And in fact I think the same results can be achieved using more dedicated digital topologies on current fabs (3nm, 2nm, etc...) and probably at comparable wattages. What these guys have achieved is amazing, but... I'm skeptical that the methods are capable of scaling in density.

It is a bit of a misdirection to say that GPUs burn hundreds of watts... that's only true when you overclock the GPU, and its only true because the architecture is very general purpose (most of the power is burned just shoving data around). Running a GPU with the correct architecture at lower frequencies... for example, running it at 500MHz instead of 1.5GHz, results in far lower power consumption. And running a dedicated topology multiplies the density by a huge factor over using a general purpose GPU.

Another thing about GPUs... the topology doesn't have to use a fixed bit width. One can run 16 bits, 12 bits, even 8 bit arithmatic, as well as use iterative loops for that arithmatic instead of fast digital multipliers to increase circuit density and reduce power consumption.

I think digital is ultimately going to win here.

The analog chips seem like an obvious energy/heat/material save for the actual processing but can they actually make training faster? Unless the whole system from input to output is analog then aren't you still running up against the Von Neumann bottleneck during training or during any on field application that requires processing large continuous stacks of data? It would be interesting to see an entirely analog robot, starting with something simple like a Roomba type device. And continuous analog inputs and outputs are easy enough to get with something like that, with solar panels and motors, but analog reward systems that prevent crashing and reward exploring new territory are a trickier problem.

Well if you look at how the neuron fires inside its self it goes from electric potential change to a chemical output to stop lost of signal.

In this case it does mean digital to neuron and then the decision to fire is analog then it sends out a digital signal forward

So by putting the two together you are actually recreating a neuron. Now there is probably a specific number of analog calculations that can be done before needing to pass on the signal digitally (making the single "neuron" able to do much more before adding in the speed limitation of passing on the signal) somthing else that is missing is not only do neurons fire down to a fixed point > they also fire back out into the rest of the system creating a bit of feed back loop proving the training/reinforcement but also refineing the signal back through as parts of it have been dulled and sharpen. Allowing for some of the earlier parts to fire or not fire increasing certainty.

Honestly, both Digital and Analog have their purposes. As you said in the video, analog computers are singe-purpose devices, or perhaps more accurately single-program devices. You would have the security camera send its data through an analog computer to recognize objects, as the main example. However, for free-form computing like web-browsing, word processing, database access, and even receiving/accessing the data from that security camera system, you want a digital computer that can run multiple programs.

Computing devices were always mostly digital, inc the mechanical devices of the 19th century and the electromechanical punched card systems from the 1890s to 1950s. People always leave that part out, but the history goes less like analog->digital than digital digital digital tiny bit of analog digital digital digital. This video is super interesting, but when you look at that history, there are other questions that are just as important as analog vs digital, such as programming interface (whether control is linguistic), independence and parallelism of calculating elements, what role temporary storage serves, etc.

The video explains quite nicely but I feel it lacks depth toward what is being done currently in the field of innovative computing. I would say that digital-analog-digital way of handling computations fast is just the tip of the iceberg. As a researcher in the field of innovative computing, there are a lot of new paradigms which can address problems of the von-Neumann's architecture, towards general computing chips and AI chips. I will list a few of them here.

Improving von-Neumann bottlenecks on General purpose chips
-Usage of NCFET's instead of conventional FET to break the voltage non-scaling issue (Lower power consumption).
-Usage of FeFET's instead of conventional SRAM cells to create a very small area in-chip memory.

Improving AI and AI chips
- Combining both type of transistors above can help solve issues with in chip memory size as well as computation power.
- Use better approaches for AI algorithms. One of these approaches is called brain inspired computing or neuromorphic computing. Same as the brain performs pattern matching, brain inspired computing matches different vectors in a huga space. Then use a similar technique to the one displayed in the video to make all the computations inside the memory (non von-Neumann architecture, My current research focus)

I am quite excited towards the direction of the research towards the field of innovative computing. There are a lot more ideas which I have not mentioned here.
At the end it all comes down to what the industry will implement in the future. They tend to keep the same fabrication line and make small changes to it rather then to replace the entire line of production, so giant leaps are not to be expected anytime soon. I believe that we will see very soon NCFET transistors used for IoT chips, being followed by implementations on general purpose chips.

There's a major issue being overlooked in the way things are presented in this video.

The really expensive and complex part is training, which is an iterative process using backpropagation where you get the weights to use. Once you have these weights, running the network (called inference) is far cheaper and simpler than training it.

The issue here is that the video is selling the idea that analog computers could make everything better, like reducing the big energy consumption of training, but then it proceeds to show applications that are limited to inference only. A quick look at Mythic AI’s website will show you that what they do is indeed inference.

There are many approaches nowadays to improve inference. For example, mobile devices often use quantization techniques (approximating calculations with 8-bit integers), and there are some startups that go as low as a single bit. Mythic AI is also doing quantization according to their website.

In the hardware side, there are also custom hardware solutions like FPGAs and ASICs, although both are digital. It is true that analog computers can be an interesting alternative here to explore. In fact, there is even research that approximates matrix multiplications used by inference with only light and optical devices.

But all of these are still limited to inference only. Improving that is certainly great, but it’s only the smaller part of the full problem. The way things are presented in this video can easily make you think it’s not the case.

It's not exactly true that digital processing has reached the end, hypothetically at least. That's true of processors based on the electron. The electron is relatively heavy compare to other subatomic particles and has a lot of resistance when using semi-conductors. That's where the problems comes in, after we get below a certain microscopic size electrons are known to spontaneously jump from one semi-conductor circuit path to a neighboring one. This makes them unreliable in terms of accuracy and stability. Without the accuracy, digital electronics are essentially useless.

There is potential for computations to be done with photons and possibly other subatomic particles, or possibly on even smaller scales such as quarks or at the quantum level, but those ideas and research are still in relative infancy. Photonics shows a lot of promise because photons don't have the physical limitations that electrons have when they employed in a semiconductor, namely heat output, stability and slower physical transmission speed. At the moment we still have to convert photons to electrons at certain points in conventional circuitry. That's an area where, currently, we lose any advantages we get from photons.

Great video. I think it would be a bit more accessible if it started with a little explanation of what analog actually means. A nice example is how a sound wave can actually be carved into something (similar to a vinyl record). The shape of the grooves are “analogous” to the real wave, this is why running a needle over them actually vibrates to reproduce the sound—in this case the information (the signal) is not coded (digital). In essence analog computers just leverage the raw physics of reality. The reason an “analog computer” can easily solve differential equations is because this is already the math that physicists and engineers use to describe the signals in the first place.

As a photographer, I feel like you learn how to use certain settings to be able to photograph the way you want to photograph.    If you want to be able to fire shots off quickly, you want your settings for faster shutter speeds, and allowing more light, and a lower ISO.   The thing is.  The more analog parts of your system that is tuned to "just work" make it easier and faster for the digital elements of your system to be also faster and more accurate.  So, if you can have your shutter work analog, and the processor tells it when to fire, you hit the optimal speed for shooting.  The analog and digital systems have to be able to compliment each other to avoid bottlenecks.  If it takes 1/60th of a second for the shutter to click, the sensor has to be up to processing the image at that speed, too.  So, if you were designing an analog/digital neural network, you'd need some analog elements that are as close to instantaneous as possible, with a digital control system that can take advantage of that speed, as well.

AGI is literally not dependent on the hardware. AGI is a collection of - Software - modules (systems) that runs on anything that will support it. Human Brain level AGI can run on a 1990s IBM DOS computer.  The mobile phone in your hand could support millions of AGIs.  The systems of the human brain are very simple and do specific tasks.  These modular systems interact with other systems through an api exchange of distilled, relevant information. For example, the decision module is supported by summarized tidbits of information processed by the "emotion" module (happy sad angry etc), the "belief" module, the "proposed action" aka "idea" module, the "5 senses" aka "feelings" module (like sight, touch, taste, smell, hearing), the short & long term memory modules, etc. The body has a balance module, a move arm module, a move hand module, a move eyes module, etc. You can read the "state" of each of these modules to help form a "decision" on an "idea" (proposed action). The brain is not as complex as people think it is.  It is a collection of interacting logic modules (systems) that are hardware independent.

During WW2, over a decade before the analogue computers mentioned in this video, the Mk 15 Norden Bombsight was probably the first military use of an analogue computer. It was used by the US Army, the US Navy, the British RAF and Fleet Air Arm. Its inputs could include aircraft pressure altitude, airspeed, direction of flight, wind speed, wind direction, target position and target altitude above Mean Sea Level. It also interacted with an autopilot system. Its output was essentially the bomb release mechanism. The bombsight allowed for much more accurate targeting than was reliably possible for an unassisted bomb aimer.

Huh. I am an engineer, and have a pretty good knowledge and concept about how computers work - both analog and digital. I design systems that can be both analog and digital and intermix them freely according to function.
I've also lately taken up a deep study of human and animal biology, particularly the latest advances in DNA manipulation, our ability to modify our own genome and the functions of the many thousands of types of proteins we produce. There are some 50,000 different types of molecules in us, and we know what 2% of them do (learning more every day). So about 1000 of them, we have a slight grasp of.
Our brain functions are also highly complex, regardless of how neurons work, and again, many thousands of molecules and proteins are involved, including many functions having to do with transcription factors and epigenetic influences.
When an AI system has more than 50,000 different types of devices in its computing system, then it may come close to human brain level thinking. Right now, there are no more than 100 or 200 generalized devices that engineers have at their disposal for the creation of an AI device. The best it will ever do will be to mimic human thinking, until it can reach levels of complexity on the order of 20,000 different types of devices.
Moreover, I've yet to hear of an AI computer that makes use of two independent brains (what we have), only having a tiny connection between them (as we have - a corpus collosum), and a competition between the two sides for dominance, one side more intuitive (analog) and the other more analytic (digital). Without this internal conflict and the need to find a way to survive in spite of it, no AI machine can ever approach the human level of thinking/intuiting/feeling/sensing/moving that we do. Toss into all of that, the billions of sensory inputs that all typical humans have to process on a moment-by-moment basis. And then walk and talk at the same time.
I think AI has a pretty long way to go. People seem terrified that AI machines will take us over. Long before AI is able to do that, we'll have already modified our own genome and become superhumans. We can improve our own thinking capacity, memory, physical strength, and any number of superior abilities.
By the time AI catches up with where we are today, we may already be working on our own upgrades beyond superhuman.

Digital means discrete ON/OFF 0/1 Binary
Analog is a number value that is stored in system memory as a floating data type. Numbers can be between 0-1 in the form of fuzzy logic from completely true to completely false.
Fuzzy logic is used in process control theory as algorithms, capable of recognizing, representing, manipulating and interpreting information by using data driven models. These models are vague in principle because they lack certainty. Fuzzy models or sets are mathematical means of representing vagueness and imprecise information, hence the term fuzzy.

Analog "computers" are generalizations of proportional controllers. The behavior of these systems can be analyzed and predicted using feedback control theory. Neural network-based machine learning works by weighted-matrix pattern recognition. Since the matrix weighting is fine-tuned by arbitrary training examples, the behavior of neither digital nor analog neural networks can be algorithmically analyzed nor predicted by control theory. Substituting analog circuitry for digital memory banks in neural networks is simply a power consumption and cost reduction technique, not a fundamental change in the machine learning process.

"Our brains are digital, a neuron either firing or not firing."  Nope! Our neurons are always firing, but at various frequencies. And each firing (depolarization) creates a digital impulse that is summed into an analog accumulator to help control the firing frequency of another neuron. So our brains are both digital and analog. After the flood disaster of 1952, the Dutch decided to deal with the threat of the sea once and for all. To better understand all the dynamics of rivers and estuaries, they built in analogue computer in 1955, called the "Deltar". It was dismantled in the 1980s and probably largely lost, although some sections have survived. So you could argue that millions of people are protected from drowning, based on the work of an analogue computer.

The machine has always fascinated me. It was huge, as computers in the 1950s were wont to be, but you can actually spot the similarities with "The Analog Thing". There was a table where you could set up different configurations using cables. But there isn't a lot of information available about how it actually worked.

I think we could see a comeback in analog computing, not on its own, but as a complimentary to digital computing. An analog computer that has its inputs and outputs all handled and verified by a digital host computer, could provide consistent and accurate results, and any variation in part quality, something that would normally throw off an analog computer, could be filtered out via an LUT system, where the digital computer could send in a bunch of values with known answers, and calibrate accordingly.
Not only could this solve variation and inconsistency in analog computing, but this could also enable analog computing to become multi-purpose, as the digital computer could easily handle sending different types of information through, using LUTs to also correct for skew caused by using different amounts of inputs, and potentjometers in the pre-computing phase to adjust bias of each input.

yes! digital computers have suffered because they lack highly distributed and independent processing. the brain has billions of neurons, all working on their own power, firing completely independently, and with an analog signals of course, but also having thousands (or sometimes hundreds of thousands) of connections. neural network architectures are nothing like this, and thus will never achieve a general capability to associate pieces of data based on context. instead, they will just be another model loosely based on the brain, performing excessively numerous calculations which require way more nodes than should be needed.

One thing of note, our transistors can never be a single atom, it's a conductor wrapped around a resistor, there's just no way to do that with anything less than 3 atoms and they can't do that yet. As lithography gets smaller they find that the design of the transistor itself keeps changing, what worked on 14nm doesn't really work well on 10nm or 7nm, often various components become relatively larger even though overall the design has shrunk.

If we had stuck with a lower power usage similar to the air cooled 4x86 then we could make transistors differently, smaller, but we went for clock speed and performance, so the transistors are insanely complex and much, much, much larger than an atom.

Overall good video - I thought the exploration of the history of AI was very accessible. One really important detail that I think you could have highlighted more effectively is the difference between training a model, and deploying the model. The Mythic AI engineer spoke to this, however an untrained ear may not have understood the difference. The analog solution is great if you have a static, pre-trained model. But the 3-households worth of power to train a model is not something fixed by analog computing - the model still needs to be trained on traditional digital computers.

A further line of exploration may also show that in a quantum world, analog isn't a thing. If energy can only be released in discrete amounts, then do all analog systems reduce to a digital variant?

An analog computer can be set up to process specific calculations very quickly, as the laws of physics themselves do the calculations for you, but it means you have to make a discrete chip/computer per series of calculations you wish to do. They can only do that one job very well.

Whereas a digital computer has a layer of abstraction in the form of the transistors, so can perform many jobs pretty well and can switch jobs on the fly, but this means the transistors have to handle every step of the calculation, making them slower.


Putting the two together, just as you would a CPU and a GPU, is a brilliant idea. Take advantage of each of their strengths. Quick specific calculations and general purpose multi-tasking in one system.

Great video! I was worried at first that this would just be yet another attempt by you to normalize AI (when we should be very concern and cautious with AI). But, in fact, I was wrong (on this video). Your video correctly demonstrates a very credible hypothesis, that if we use AI, it can be better done in analog. Honestly though, even digital systems have to deal with analog and at smaller levels atomic/quantum effects. So, really, going back to analog - to me, it isn't really about the past or the future, but more so, it is about realizing we've been working in analog this whole time and just better applying it.

PS: I highly doubt that AI image recognition is better than average human performance. I highly doubt humans are in error 5% of the time (especially if we're previously told what the images are much like much AI is) especially not for more common imagery. I've seen demonstrations of how easily image and facial recognition can be trick. Surely, it is far superior (and much scarier) than it was in the past, but it has a long way to go to meet or exceed human standards. Sure, it may be able to catch an image at a faster glance, but I don't think it has as deep or accurate an understanding of the image. A little far fetched, but interesting all the better. In my opinion, there is another large-scale movement besides "analog to digital" in the last 50 years, and it is "from solution-specific systems to general purpose systems". Of course we do not know how to make "general purpose analog systems" except for the very basic idioms (such are capacitor, resistor, wire, voltage) but in the digital world - we started with specific car-engine-computers, finance-computers, photo-manipulation-computers, typesetting computers etc. towards single-device-that-does-all. This movement isn't coincidental, and isn't even just for ease and comfort (why have 2 devices where 1 can serve both uses). The real importance there is the economy of scale. When you produce a device that can only be sold to 250000 customers - it will remain expensive, and won't develop much technologically, because there cannot be sufficient return for research investment. But device that sells in hundreds of millions (such are todays leading cellphones) invite unprecedented investment. This is not black-and-white of course, and Apple's new M1 chip is taking one step back from "general purpose" as many of the functions are now moved to custom-specialized subsystems within the chip.

What I mean to say is, to become important, Analog computing must pass a threshold of generalization of the usage. There must be Analog building-blocks that can serve enough different purposes, as to drive the economy of scale, and fit into hundreds of millions of devices. Google's old-fashion GPU farms are virtually unimportant for this process - because there are so few of them. This startup in Texas may be selling to Google good and cheap GPU replacements, but that's not a start of any industry.

I'm old enough to remember the "Analog electronics" era, and still use an analog Audio system (yes, including a turntable and tube-amplifiers and all that) and being a musician I can certainly appreciate the analog sound of my Piano over its digital recording and manipulation. I'm not "against analog" - only I think something fundamental must change, and that will only happen when some electrical engineer will step out of the digital brain-washing machine in the academy and industry, and will come up with a real new idea about flexible analog systems.

You can't multiply in analog, but you can add! So the logarithmic op amp was created because you can add logarithms together, feed the result to an anti-log op amp and the result is the multiplicand!
You can also divide with the same principle by subtracting logs.
Log amps are all packaged in single chips too but they're often expensive, but Burr Brown, Analog Devices, Texas Instruments and many more make them, and they have many uses, like true RMS conversion for volt meters, and converting voltages to power for power meters.

Your model of a Neuron is ok at a teaching tool, but the real things are vastly more complex - not to mention the staggeringly complex Neural Networks formed between thousands & thousands of Neurons, as well as hundreds of Glial Cells (which may, in their own unique way, activate other Neurons/Neural Nets through messenger molecules like Neural-Hormones, Chemokines & Cytokines).

Note that while Neurons do function with an Active Potential, the information is often transmitted via a series of pulses. Things like the number of pulses (or pauses between pulses) over a unit of time, may trigger the emission of a specific Neurotransmitter (from potentially dozens) / the volume of that Neurotransmitter / period of time before Reuptake /etc..

In a single cell, there may be dozens of different types of Neurotransmitters (depending on cell type) waiting in packets called Synaptic Vesicles (which take time to get replaced), which may cross the Synapse to:
• Several Dendrites linked from a single cell, or
• Single Dendrites each linked from one of hundreds of cells,
all connected to this singular Terminal Bouton (among hundreds, some even attached to the sides of the Axon) from the original Neuron.

Changes in Neural Webs may occur with changes in the Dendrites, which are constantly proliferating / pruning / strengthening links to other Dendrites or the Terminal Buttons of neurons. Huge amounts of pruning occurs during the first five years of childhood, but new linkages are perpetually being made by the Dendrites.

Too much Exitatory Stimuli to a Neuron may cause it to exhaust it's stores of a Neurotransmitter, leave the cell with too much metabolic waste products (which is both Cytotoxic, Potentially Carcinogenic & may prematurely trigger Apoptosis).

One suspected waste product (⊚) is the pigment Melanin, which causes both the grey/blue/dark brown colours of the brain, but Neuromelanin is sent down the optic nerve to color the iris of the human eye (with so many variations due to Rayleigh scattering).


⊚ - It likely has other purposes we haven't identified, yet.

It's not as-if the engineers who design computers don't know about this.  Why did they move away from analog, anyway?  In short, we're not building computers wrong.  Digital computers are much more precise, and can achieve any level of precision desired without constant calibration or re-alignment, temperature compensation, expensive voltage or current references, etc..  In analog computers, passive components are important, and precise ones with low tempcos are quite expensive.  Digital computers can store programs, which can be debugged and re-used an infinite number of times without re-configuring anything.  Then a digital computer can run these programs (even multiple ones at the same time) at-will.  I think of an analog computer as a slide rule.  It can quickly give you a good approximation (precise enough for most purposes) of a mathematical problem, whereas a digital computer is more like a calculator- but with the capability to store and operate upon reams of data.  A lot of computer applications require massive data storage.

I wanted to point out as soon as you mentioned the difference between "analog" and "digital" that they are the same thing as far as electronics goes. It is simply a distinction of implementation. Digital electronics is as you said a collection of analog transistors arranged in such a way to get very distinct and repeatable results in noisy environments.

I am glad that you perhaps unintentionally pointed this out with the mythic ai example of using "digital" logic in a an "analog" way. Those memory cells are simply analog transistors intended to be used in a "digital" way but they can be used for whatever you like. The trick with these A/D distinctions is not what the technology is capable of but how you think of them. It is a balance of competing requirements (engineering).

It is up to us as engineers to leverage the tools scientists have refined and shown us. Boxing ourselves into thinking about any technology as "analog" or "digital" is a trap. It is a collection of tools which can be used in different ways to give you the results you want. You can't have it all so you have to choose what is most important. Digital gives us repeatability (state machines with defined start states) and noise immunity with the downside of limited resolution and speed. Analog is fast and has theoretically infinite resolution (if you can tame the pesky noise floor) but repeatability and noise are a real problem especially with fast multiplication operations. And really good analog is EXPENSIVE!

The examples you used were single-use/progression from left to right for a single calculation.  This means to increase the complexity and accuracy you increase the number of neurons/nodes.  Alternatively you could use feedback loops which more accurately represents how brains work.  When identifying something visually it is not yes or no, you resolve it over a second or two (typically) which increasing accuracy.  You can almost instantly identify the existance of possible threats but not the details of what they are.  This is a mixture of receiving enough sensorory data and processing it.  The more time taken in processing data , the more feedbacks can be used and less neurons/nodes needed.  However the complexity of iterative networks of neurons is mind-boggling, but that will be a significant step up on processing sensory data.  Also the same applies to the receiving of sensory data; you can constantly receive small but key data that can alert whether to collect more data (just like the alexa/siri word detection), and over time you collect finer details and the processing deems it necessary.  This is working in the limitation of the processing power available (eg small brain or large brain) and how to distribute data collection with data processing and the power used.  The simplification used in your video that can be relexed is that the neuron outputs ones or zeros; nerons release many chemical signals of different strengths, and some axons branch that reach multiple destination neurons.  In addtion clusters of neurons specialise allowing for more complex interactions.

On a side-note, "the end of Moore's Law" has been being predicted since somewhere in the mid-1980s (even then also claiming that the laws of physics wouldn't allow going further), and still hasn't actually happened yet. Frankly, I'll believe it when I see it, but until then anyone who claims it is just chicken-little'ing IMHO.

In particular, I note that we're still mostly doing all of our digital IC designs basically in 2D. I expect sometime in the fairly near future a lot of this stuff will be transitioning to more layered 3D designs (we've already seen some manufacturers starting to venture in that direction) which would allow cramming far more transistors into roughly the same form factor chips, so no, I don't think we're actually going to be hitting the limits of what digital computing can do any time soon, to be honest.

I like the idea of using semi-programmable analog devices and think it's real cool tech. My one niggling doubt is the fact there is no such thing as error correction for analog devices. There are sources of noise that screw with the output of analog devices that digital devices are good enough at error correcting to take into account. So, I imagine for something like autonomous cars you will need both to make sure the behavior is always on point. I work quite a bit with analog devices, so know there are big challenges to get an analog system to behave how you expect 100% of the time. It might be good enough for certain tasks where there is low risk and you have certain constraints for energy use, space, etc. But for autonomous cars the difference between having something that works 100% of the time and 99.9% of the time is a lot of people dying. I assume, however, that Mythic has thought about this when designing. I imagine their chips are well shielded and you can get near perfect performance in that small form factor.

In your list of drawbacks for analog computers, you forgot (IMHO) a rather big one: Unreliable.

The physical world is a constantly changing and very noisy place. There are all kinds of things that can affect electronics to change voltage levels and currents slightly, or sometimes even in large ways, over time. One of the huge benefits to digital logic (and actually why it was first developed) is that it makes it possible to distinguish, at a low level, between correct values and invalid conditions, and know reliably whether the device is functioning as intended or not.

In a digital computer, if a "1" is 5 volts and a "0" is 0 volts, those are the only valid possibilities (within certain margins). If a logic line ends up with 2.5 volts or -5 volts, those are obviously fault conditions and will usually cause things like crashes, and stop processing altogether. But if a value in an analog computer is supposed to be 5V but ends up 2.5V, or even -5V, it will just come up with a different answer than it should, with no indication of a problem at all. When reliability is particularly important, the precision of digital computing also allows conclusive checking to make sure things are actually still correct (parity/ECC codes, etc), which you can't really do with analog values either. This is particularly an issue with anything intended to operate for long periods of time, because electronic components and operating conditions change over time, so even if it started out doing the right thing reliably, there's no guarantee it will stay that way over the long term.

As a direct example, the analog matrix multiplication chip towards the end, I would suspect is actually far far more sensitive to external electrical or magnetic fields than any traditional computer. The digital equivalents are, yes, much larger and less efficient, but also likely much more resilient to real-world conditions, which is often important.

Some of this can sometimes be dealt with by simply "over-engineering" things (for example, having two, three, or more of each computer doing the same calculations at the same time and comparing the results to make sure they match), but that can also reduce some of the touted benefits (simplicity, efficiency) as well, so the benefits of analog computing often don't end up being as large as they might seem at first, for many applications.

One issue that is a little glossed over here is that that conversion to digital and back to improve signal integrity is quite costly. The ADC (analog-to-digital converter) is a power hungry component that has limits in terms of bit resolution which gets worse with increasing frequency. For example, a 1-ghz 8-bit ADC (considered top of the line) allows you to convert an analog signal to an 8 bit digital number at a speed of 1 ghz - BUT only 8 bits… So if you’re summing say sixteen 8 bit numbers together as part of the matrix multiply and accumulate, you would expect to end up with a 12-bit wide result (e.g. 255 x 16 = 4080 which requires at least 12 bits to represent). If your ADC is only 8 bits, then you’re losing some of that resolution!

Either way, you have got to respect the creativity and ingenuity from the folks at Mythic. Taking solid state memory and turning it into compute is the type of inventiveness that keeps pushing tech forwards.

Here's some more detail from an AI researcher perspective that Derek had to skip over:

1. (on 4:15 and 20:08 ) Neurons actually exhibit non-digital characteristics. Checkout all the complex chemical and enzyme interactions simulated in "Neuromorphic engineering": these are the researchers seriously pursuing bio-inspired artificial neurons.
2. As such, the perceptron has always been a crude model of real neurons and neural network engineering since then has only made it diverge further. For example, we have replaced the digital thresholding on the matrix multiplication with either just passing it straight on (linear gates) or rounding negative values up to zero (rectified linear gates, called ReLu for short). At this point the name "neural" network is a bit misleading, so most practitioners treat it as a vestigial name rather than a real parallel. Introducing modern neural networks via the shaky biomimetic parallel invites the kinds of "artificial brain" rhetoric that hyped AI into the first AI winter.
3. (on 12:18) As Derek says, what AlexNet added was greater depth and way more neurons. Therefore, the jury is out on whether the AlexNet breakthrough, and its ensuing deep learning revolution, was from the neural network structure itself or from the sheer adjustable depth of the network that AlexNet brought. There are many successful learning algorithms that get comparable performance to neural networks just by going deep even when discarding the neural network structure. For example, check out how even simple linear controllers can beat neural networks in the research from Ben Recht's group at UC Berkeley
4. (on 13:20 ) The fact that they are "performing better than human labeling" when the ImageNet data comes from human labels suggests that the AI is fitting to information beyond the tolerance of the data. This fitting to match noise (termed "overfitting" for short) is characteristic of deeply parametrized learning models. By overfitting the AI generally only works well on the dataset and can't generalize what it's learned to new cases. Therefore, the standard in deep learning application is to secure quite large datasets and keep the AI working only within conditions like those in the training set. Though we hope for AI to intelligently extend to novel situations, that transfer has yet to materialize. The closest we've got is just rapidly gathering more data live when we're placed in a new scene, which we can prep for via "meta-learning" (see Chelsea Finn's research)

Combining points 3 and 4, it's my opinion that the advances in deep AI comes from bigger data sets (thanks to people like Fei Fei Li) and having more tunable parameters to fit this data. *Big data and robust computation are the game changers*. We AI researchers really owe a lot of our success to the systems engineers and database managers who brought that heat.

Comparing an analog computer to a CPU or GPU is a bad comparison. It's purpose-built vs general computing hardware.
The correct comparison would be to compare the analog computers introduced at the end to FPGAs and ASICs. FPGAs being programmable computing blocks and ASICs being purpose-built for one specific equation. In terms of flexibility an analog computer with programmable weights would be somewhere between those two.
ASICs in particular also tend to be far, far more energy efficient than the GPU that was used as a comparison to the analog computer in this video.

Neurons are not simple on off devices like transistors. Imagine you have a transistor where the doping atoms quantum entangle with the doping atoms of other nearby transistors. These entanglements serve to adjust the bias voltage causing the transistor to turn on sooner or later than expected. This is how our brainwaves are modulated by individual quantum entanglements within the neuron microtubules. Obviously it is an incredibly complicated functional layer of our neural nets, and why these simulated neural nets are always useless in comparison to the human brain. We can do some cool things with these rudimentary neural nets but it is nothing near the level of technology in human brain neurons.

@Veritasium Great breakdown, and I'm glad to see this kind of content from you again. A couple of notes:
Neurons, based on a recent study, are not toggle on or off. It is a gradient input which spikes at levels we can detect, but continues as a gradient over time (ref: Queensland Brain Institute - How do neurons work? )
Also, you might look into the use of glass as a medium for etching AI pathways for analog analysis. In this the trained network (with biases, if I understand correctly) is etched into glass. Then to determine if something matches the trained algorithm's pattern, light is shone into one side and the result shines out the other. For reference see Neural Network in Glass Requires No Power, Recognizes Numbers on Hackaday's site.

An excellent and timely presentation! Thank You
The first computer I worked on professionally was designed before Apollo. It was used on the F4 Phantom with gyros and accelerometers to navigate the jet fighter and deliver complex weapons. When properly tuned, it worked very well and was reliable. Sure later digital units eventually came out but these analog systems could not be knocked by cosmic rays as all the calculation were done in real time. Key variables were literal gear and shaft clockworks while inputs and outputs were generally progressively refined as analog voltages using linear algebra in the form of phase angle and Voltage differences in synchro/servo systems. Programming was baked in by the interconnections so no general purpose code was needed.
In the modern world much of this could be replicated with ASICs.
The main idea of the Apollo Guidance Computer and others, are to pre and post process everything possible in the analog realm, so the little to no time is spend running code.
We have seen great advances using GPU's because the processes are broken down to step by step flows that can be pipelined in dedicated core elements.

"Once Upon a Time" I had a lab exercise to simulate something on a tube based analog computer.  The dynamic range was +/- 100 V.  I also worked at the time in an R&D department of an industrial company, where we started discussing how we needed an analog computer of our own to simulate certain 3-layer extrusion product cooling.  So, why not?  I designed and built a 10-amplifier analog computer with semiconductor op-amps and one multiplier module as well as one 5 segment adjustable slope module.  Its dynamic range naturally was only +/- 10 V.  Then I built a "library" of plug-in 1% resistors and 1% (selected from 5%) capacitors.  We also had 10-turn dial potentiometers. as a NAND flash engineer that bit about the usage of floating gate transistors as analog computers is interesting. particular because in flash memory there is a thing known as "read disturb", where even low voltages applied to the gate (like during a flash read) to query it's state can eventually cause the state itself to change. you would think it is a binary effect where if it's low enough it would just be a harmless read but no...eventually there will be electron build up in the gate (reading it many times at low voltage has a similar effect to programming it one time at a high voltage). in this particular application the weight would increase over time the more you query it, even though you didn't program it to be that high in the beginning. it's interesting because, it's sort of analogous to false memories in our brains where the more we recall a particular memory, the more inaccurate it could potentially become.

I've always been a fan of Misha Mahowald's hybrid analog and digital neural circuits. She created a silicon "retina" chip, and a stereoscopic vision processor, as well as a communication chip that was capable of receiving a neuron pulse from a source, and communicate via a digital address system to tell which analog neurons should receive the input. It was a genius merging of analog and digital, and I always thought it had great potential. It's a fascinating look at what could have been. She studied under Carver Mead at the California Institute of Technology, and later traveled to the UK. Sadly her work and life were cut short due to her depression... I've always wondered what she could have done if she were still among the living. Your video talks of where the future might lead... People like Misha, people like myself... She'd been wondering since the start of the 1990s, and me, I wanted to know where analog-digital hybrid tech would lead since the mid 90s. I'm glad it's something being reconsidered.

There was a video documentary that focused on her work, called "Silicon Vision". It came out in the mid 1990s,and was part of PBS's "Discovering Women" series. It can be found if searched for. It's a very intriguing look at the cutting edge of 1991, in neural development, and a small taste of how analog could infuse digital with new capability!

the problem with analog computing is that at high frequencies and small scales, it is EXTREMELY vulnerable to electrical interference to the point where even the connectors plugged into it will cause enough ripple to ruin its ability to calculate anything accurately.
The shift to digital was for speed and accuracy. Analog is nice for very specific computational processes, like anything that is naturally analog like sound, but you cannot shrink it to the nano scale or run tens of thousands of operations per second on them.
This is why digital devices don't actually operate on 1 and 0, they operate on a RANGE of voltages where anything above a threshold is seen as a 1, and anything below it is a 0. This leaves room for interference and voltage fluctuations and the natural resistance, ripple, and capacitance that happens at nano scales and very low voltages.

The title is misleading, the 'analog computer' isn't some lost tech that's getting neglected. Analog electronics implement equations using circuits and digital electronics is just a special sub case where you operate with two distinct voltage levels. Even in digital circuits, there are plenty of issues that needs to be handled in the analog domain. The perspective being presented here is just ass backwards.

It often comes down to specialized vs. general. Digital computations are not efficient, but they are precise and you can simulate practically anything with them. You might just need a lot of power and time. Analog systems have to be more specially designed. This chip is amazing at matrix multiplication, which in this application is excellent, but isn't necessarily useful in other ways. And heck, a GPU isn't ideal for most tasks either, that's why we still have CPUs which are even more general.

But most computers don't have just one kind of processor. The modern CPU is also a GPU, and has a bunch of different sub-processors optimized for different things. And below that, various parts of the CPU perform different kinds of calculations. The future will likely be analog processing units tacked on with digital ones. Neither can do everything, but we can make chips that contain both.

Analog computing is intrinsically faster, more efficient, more accurate, and more powerful at many tasks.
But it can't easily be "programmed" or "reprogrammed". Without physically rewiring the hardware.
This is why it was quickly supplanted by digital computing. Computers you could program and reprogram again and again with software.
But now we have cheap, fast, powerful digital computers which can help us design cheaper, faster, more powerful analog computers for specific programmed tasks very quickly and easily.

I've been saying for the last 20 years: The best neural networks are neurons comprising an innately analog processing system. And in the last 20 years we've been accumulating knowledge and processes for manipulating and creating biological systems at a pace akin to Moore's Law.

As my own two children were approaching college age I suggested to them that their generation of computer engineers and programmers would be bio-engineers. Alas they each went for the more traditional fields of mechanical and civil engineering.

I do understand and respect the ethical concerns regarding developing and modifying biological systems - beings. But in spite of Roger Penrose' opinions on the matter, I think we will run into precisely the same ethical problems if we succeed in melding digital and analog electronics into real Intelligence. I just think that's a dead-end because the biological approach is more efficient in scale per volume, energy consumption and heat dissipation than any purely electronic system can achieve.

As an analog expert for the last 50 years, retired now, I see the analog future interesting but ultimately a specialist niche for doing specific tasks as part of what are mostly digital systems. I made my money for all these years doing stuff with op amps but ultimately they were for feeding data into digital systems and for taking digital data and making it relevant again for the analog world we live in. But I have done some amazing stuff starting with the µA709 and the TL072. I have probably had my designs use a million LM324s. It is sort of odd that the most used op amps are still ones designed in the 1970s. Because once we have a favorite that does the job, we stick with it.

I have also done a ton of high end audio work and for that chip op amps have not proved good enough and for the highest grade audiophile systems, I there are products I have designed that use discreet component op amps with 3 to 9 discrete transistors that are still in production to this day.

You said in this video something that seems to be a common belief but which is completely wrong. Yes, it takes tremendous resources (in compute time AND in storage of training data and such) to train a large neural network. You need a datacenter, pretty much. But to RUN the neural net? To use it to get answers? You can run that on a potato. Once you have the weights... that's all you need. Then each use is just a big matrix multiplication. ALL of the problems you outline have a solution... it's not analog. It's 1 device: the memristor. Producing them in large quantity is still challenging, as they were only proven to exist a handful of years ago. But, if we can master their manufacturing the way we have with transistors.... well, literally everything is going to change. They were hypothesized to exist as the 4th 'fundamental circuit element' in the 1970s. And now we know they do exist, and we can make them. And in operation they behave like a resistor with a memory. So when current passes through it in one direction, their resistance increases. When current passes through it in the opposite direction, resistance decreases. Using this it is possible to reproduce everything in modern computers using only a grid of memristors. Memory, CPU, anything. Imagine an FPGA which can be reprogrammed faster than any cache memory on a CPU die can change state. Oh, and it is non-volatile. It need not remain powered or be refreshed to retain its resistance level. All data storage, all CPUs, all GPUs, all FPGAs, everything can be replaced by just a gigantic grid of memristors. AND they do MORE than that. Since they basically act a hell of a lot like a neuron, there is a ton of research being done into "neuromorphic computing" which doesn't seek to emulate circuits but, instead, brains. Memristors function somewhat like neurons. I find that much less interesting than the OTHER thing they can do... they can't just function as CPU or memory... they can change what they are functioning as nearly instantaneously. This makes possible completely unthinkable algorithms. Algorithms where compute units literally exist electrically directly connected to memory holding the data they are operating on, and changing whether they store data or execute computations in realtime. Data locality on the chip becomes as important as the value being stored, computing "moving" around the grid computing by creating paths to and setting the values it needs. It is an utterly bizarre and fundamentally different mean of computation, and we don't know anything about what it might make possible. It required a lot of ground-up reworking of all existing computing concepts.

If you can't tell, I'm pretty excited for these things.

edit: wtf? You dive right into memristors, which are NOT an analog computing model at all, after setting it up to claim analog computers will be significant in the future. Obviously I commented in my excitement before finishing the video. Sorry about that. But you undersold memristors and classing them as analog just isn't right. Current either flows or it does not, which is digital. But that's getting a bit into semantics. We already COULD have extremely low power devices doing ALL voice recognition. And it could be adaptive and actually work BETTER and not require an Internet connection. That's already a cakewalk. The reason your Google Home or Amazon Echo sends every word you say to a datacenter is NOT because it is computationally expensive to recognize and process your voice. The reason it does it is purely and totally for business reasons. By processing your speech, they get to collect data on you. If the little bit of computation needed was done on the device itself? It would cut them, and the advertisers they sell your data to, out of the loop. It would destroy their business model. It's the same reason you don't see videos the recommendation algorithm thinks YOU will like, your tastes are balkanized into a group and you're shown what the algorithm determines your GROUP likes. If recommenders ran locally in your browser instead of in the cloud, it would be easy, they could have infinite memory, but it would give YOU the data and there'd be no reason to send it off to advertiser-friendly balkanizing algorithms that can't handle the idea of 'individuals'.

The research and products that they are doing at Mythic can be a huge step forward in Computer Vision since very complex CV deep neural models can be run in small, fast and low power-consuming hardware. For many CV applications a certain level of noise can be tolerated and still give a useful result. This is related also with the fact that the input itself has noise and distortion, so the model must be robust and tolerate it.

I'm a bit afraid for the fact that the same kind of hardware could be used on deep neural models built for other things, such as NLP or prediction over time-series of any kind. For these topics, the input hasn't got a natural noise, but running such neural models over analogue, non-deterministic hardware would introduce noise, with unpredictable results.

The versatility of a device is a huge factor. For example, I have a kindle which is super light, can store hundreds of books and the battery will last weeks. I also have a latest gen iPad which can read any e-book format, and do so many other things. It weighs a lot more and the battery will last at most 8-10 hours. A specialized device for reading allows me to bring up a text book and then type on the iPad. So, rather than carrying a half-dozen text books, easily 20-30 lbs, I have a specialized device to take their place. 

Then again, I can write out a slew of notes in the margins of a real book, and even do the same on an e-book on my iPad. Both help me to not only remember the material better, but referring back to the text for quotes is easier because I know the page I'm looking for because of my "mark-ups." Ultimately, I love both and both are useful for work on the road, as well as leisure.
