Memristors. The virtually ignored fundamental electrical component, alongside resistors, inductors, capacitors, … capable of analog information storage (think: a byte per, or two… whatever the resolution of your analog-to-digital converter is) or, in a lattice arrangement, capable of replacing transistors at much higher densities. Talking terabytes per cubic centimetre, here. Even a single memristor is capable of simulating a neuron; it can "learn", and not in a binary way. This could blow Moore's law out of the water, in terms of the current limitations of transistor size, and storage density. (RAM uses a capacitor and three transistors per BIT…)

And not these floating electron approaches; oxygen propagation in a bimetallic join. Immune to EMPs, for example, and actually permanent for the lifespan of the metals involved. (Chemical, not electrical storage.)

Analog computers can be several orders of magnitude faster and consume for less power than digital computers. Digital approach is brute force and more precise, but no one cares about precision below a fraction of a percent in many applications. Tuning can reduce absolute error and they can be made to track environmental variations through clever engineering. They deal with real world signals much better. One major issue is that analog signal processing needs true electrical/electronic engineers, not software coders.

When I was in High School (30 years ago) I remember an activity my biology teacher did to help us appreciate our senses. He had 11 items (he told us there were 10 items) in a black velvet bag. I don’t remember exactly but it was a couple groups of similar items: baseball, orange, racketball, AA battery, AAA battery, dice, (blue) square lego, pencil, Bic pen, action figure.

He then told us to reach in and pick out items based on descriptions only, no pictures. He then requested things like: the item you would eat; the item you can erase; the item you hit with a bat, the item with dots on all sides; the smaller energy source; the blue item,…the other item that might be blue.

We were able to easily “see” with our fingers what he described based on descriptions. He then laid out examples of all 10 items and asked us to reach in and grab the item that wasn’t displayed. That is when we found out there were 11 items. So we then had to examine all the items and then determine which was different. If we hadn’t noticed already that was when we “saw” the tennis ball.

I often think of the differential processes that we were able to accomplish with no “training”. I wonder if AI will ever be able to handle those tasks that were so relatively simple for humans!

One of the most common use cases for analog computers is indeed when accuracy is not critical. But not accuracy in say it's always 1% off: also in signal to noise ratio. Keeping noise low in analog costs alot of power.
A 8-bit number has a dynamic range of about 50dB. A 16-bit number has a dynamic range of about 98dB. A 32-bit number (which are still commonly used on many computers) has a dynamic range of 194.4dB.
If you look at the power of noise in a 1Hz bandwidth, the noise floor is around -174dBm. That means that if you want to represent a "32-bit" range number in analog, the signal needs to swing up to 20.4dBm, which is around 100mW. Limited to 1Hz bandwidth. Meanwhile modern computers can do millions of 32-bit additions, multiplications, subtractions in that power envelope.

The trouble is when digital computers need to be scaled down. Suppose we have an analog and digital computer than can do a particular 32-bit operation at similar rates. The analog computer takes 1W (30dBm), and the digital computer takes 1uW (-30dBm). At what resolution, or dynamic range, would the analog computer win? Well.. analog computers scale with the order of magnitude necessary. Digital computers scale only to the number of bits.
That means that if you cut the resolution of that digital computer by 4 to only 8-bit, it would consume 0.25uW. For an analog computer however, you can reduce the power needed by 2^24.. meaning it will consume 0.06uW. Imagine if you only need 6, 5 or 4 bits..

Value of a analogue chip shown here is not that is analogue but it that isn't constrained by limitation called "Von Neumann bottleneck". In practice, modern computers have separate parts for memory and computation. And the need for synchronization of those parts is called "Von Neumann bottleneck". This bottleneck is deeply intertwined with a computer architecture to a point that it cannot be overcome. Math (non-von Neumann) doesn't tolerate statement like a = a + 1 - it is a nonsensical thing to say. But on von Neuman devices this statement is a firing sequence of synchronizations across memory and computational parts of device (load value A from memory to a computational part, increment it on computational part, store it back to a memory over the old value).

Non-von Neumann computers, in digital or analogue, forms are holly grail for some modes of computations - like matrix manipulation. There has been everlasting desire of Computer Scientist to design a proper memory module which can also compute. For recent example of fully general non-von Neumann computer see Hewlett-Packard memristors technology and The Machine project.

Historically von Neumann digital computers are much easier to mass design and mass produce. As each part of computer is developed in proper technology by different groups of people. So they tend to be faster because of economics, not because conceptual superiority. Computer chip show in this video is good example of failures of non-von Neumann device. This computer has inputs in current voltage (V) and output in current strength (A). Thus the same devices switches between Voltage and Current logic design - a very hard thing to design for. The usage of Current logic is the actual limitation why they need to stop and revert calculation to digital domain every now and then. The amps just dilute over circuit.

Anyway, analog computers never really went away. They do have their place. "Operational amplifier" is widely used and perfectly fine computer. It certainly solves differential equations much faster than me. We are just not used to call them "computers".

Analogue computers are great for graph functions, but quantization cannot occur whilst the function is running; the machine must run as a homogeneous function from start to finish. This is great if you want to avoid the calculus which bridges discrete/continuous domains, but not so good if you don't want a homogeneous machine; most applications require/demand levels of quantization in order to preserve generality. Analogue machines were once an amusing proposition, but most scientists prefer to do the calculus in the discrete domain where both limits and entropy are known.

WOW - in the early 1990s, I was working in the US Air Force as a Tech Controller (basically a pre-internet Network Management Centre, but with layer 1 and 2 line-of-sight microwave links, telephone switches and analog voice and data line patching - with literal patch cords, like a olde-tymey telephone operator would use).

It was nothing like this, but how it relates is we had one line-of-sight communication system that used analog multiplexing, and a larger one that used digital time-division multiplexing.

How the analog one worked, is you'd take a reference frequency, and modulate - "vibrate" it if you like - with the signal of a phone/audio line.
So you'd take a 4kHz frequency, and modulate it with "channel 1" on "Trunk 1", and a 8kHz frequency and modulate it with "Channel 2" audio, 12khz with "Channel 3" and so on up to 12 channels. Then you'd simply combine those together with what amounts to a fancy mixer - like a DJ would audio mix two sounds together - to get one "audio" signal, with 12 voice calls at the same time, each one 4kHz higher - up on beyond the range of human hearing. To imagine what it "sounded" like, imagine you are listening to a normal voice speaking at the same time as another voice with the pitch increased to make it a bit squeeky, and then a third to make it REALLY squeeky, and another higher one, and so on beyond your range of hearing.
It sounded pretty wierd!
So then, you take that "audio", and another 3 and do the same again - but this time the second one is modulated by a 96kHz signal, the third by a one yet 96kHz higher than than, and so on.
That gives you a mega-"squeeky" audio signal with 48 audio signals, each 4kHz higher than the previous one.

This massive analog signal was called a "supertrunk". You could then combine another supertrunk the same way to get two combined (at least on that system).
You then just vibrate a microwave radio frequency with the massive analog supertrunks - usually a 4gHz or 8gHz signal.

But obviously, you can only fire a line-of-sight microwave beam just so many miles before the curvature of the earth became a problem, or just attenuation as that signal diffracted nicely over hills etc.
So you'd put a repeater which just rebroadcast the single supertrunk signal out of one analog output from the radio and straight into the other.
And each repeater added noise and a degree of distortion.

NOW.
The "noise floor" of this system on a single link of 30-odd miles was literally around -78dBM.
For you audio freaks, that means we were beaming literally hundreds of phone calls (albeit, limited to an upper audio frequency of about 3.4kHz, so it was pretty AM quality frequency-wise) with the noise of a VERY high quality LP or cassette tape WITH Dolby B, C, S or even DBX switched on (all you Tascam freaks might remember that stuff - good times, good times.)
HOWEVER, each repeater site to get it across the murky UK air would add around 6-9DB more noise. By the time it got from London to the other side of Oxfordshire, you'd be lucky to hear anyone at the other end.

Now the other system was digital - you just digitise the audio, and stack the channels up one bit at a time, more or less, one after the other time wise until you get all 8 bits.
But its noise floor was -45dBM. It sounded like a bad 8-track tape...but with AM radio broadcasting over it... but it sounded that "good" for literally thousands of miles.

No real point to this convo except to say that for many applications, the tech of the 1950s/60s in purely analog worked extremely well...to a point. In many applications, it worked far, far better.
It would have been pretty straightforward to jig an old analog radio system to give you access to the bandwidth of 5 or 6 audio channels at once to give you CD quality, with a hundred channels at once, over a 30-50 mile radio shot, with sound quality which wasn't far off anything short of CD quality noise-wise.

As told me many years ago by one of its engineers, the first Concorde models used analog computers. They had many in-flight problems during initial testing because while digital variables might overflow and give unpredictable results, the analog computer boards would fry when variables overflowed resulting in higher then expected voltages and currents. It took them a while to protect every component from this, and stop burning computers in flight. As harsh as it sounds, it was reportedly not a major problem as Concorde was not really dependent on automation for safe flight. As reported by its test pilots, it was actually a pretty docile airplane.

Something similar to this that I have been looking into recently is the use of FPGAs for acceleration. In the case of AI inference implementation, the idea is pretty much the same as the Mythic chips shown: take a trained model and implement it in hardware. While FPGAs aren't analog in the sense that the output is determined by measuring the current flow, it can be thought of pretty much as if you built a physical circuit with logic gates that represents the trained model. This is almost always going to be way faster than a digital system because there is no memory access time, no putting values in registers and waiting for the ALU to perform an operation, etc. The speed limit is up to the propagation delay of the logic gates. (Yes, I know this is a fairly gross oversimplification, but hopefully it gets the basic idea across). As a matter of fact, Google and Amazon already have FPGAs as part of their cloud services to accelerate certain workloads. The main thing that currently prevents them from being much more widely implemented is the fact that there is no good method for FPGA virtualization. Cloud services (and increasingly pretty much all general purpose computers, but especially cloud services) rely on the ability to virtualize hardware so that many virtual machines can share it, but FPGAs are much harder to do this with, especially when you need to be able to dynamically change the "circuit" in the FPGA when switching between processes during execution. If we can figure out that problem, I think Mythic may be out of business. Not to mention that FPGAs are more useful in general because they can be used to implement pretty much any circuit consisting of logic gates, not just matrix multiplication/AI specific workloads. Unfortunately, as others have pointed out, all of this only serves to improve the speed and efficiency of implementation but does nothing for the huge training cost of both time and power.

yes analog computers have their uses. but the way we use computers is simply not combinable with analog systems.
analog systems are created for a singular purpose, 1 analog system does 1 specific thing. like the fancy analog computer from the start, if you want it to calculate something else, it needs to physically be rebuilt.
in the case of the pattern recognition software at the end we need digital computing to train the algorithms to then be converted to an analog system.
and it didn't even result in an actual analog system. they switch between analog and digital because the compounding inaccuracy of analog systems makes the results useless after too many operations happened, so they use analog steps to speed up otherwise lengthy digital processes. and then digitally interpret the analog data to feed it to the next analog step. so for anything that's reasonably complex, 100% analog just simply isn't an option unless you can get rid of any and all inaccuracies.(meaning you'd basically need to have circuitry that's 100% pure at an atomic level )

thing is... even if we get to 0% inaccuracy... when looking at how we use our computers (and other devices) analog is simply not feasible. we use our pcs for so many vastly different things and expect to be able to install whatever software we need and have it work straight from the start. just trying to have an analog pc do 1% of what a digital pc can, would be a massive undertaking. Digital won the 'fight', cause it's a system that can do whatever you want it to, without needing to be rebuilt.

however, what i do agree with is that analog could be a really good idea for minor computational devices, like typical IoT type stuff. items that are built for 1 single purpose. making them analog would make them more efficient and faster, and whatever data they provide could then be interpreted in a digital system.
maybe even standardizing certain processes into analog processing units to supplement the standard digital processing and speed up otherwise lengthy digital calculations. (which has it's own issues etc)

so yes, combining analog and digital can be a good idea. but no, we aren't building pc's wrong.

We’re a big part, if not the biggest part, of the inefficiency that necessitates digital computing. Without quantized, absolute values, we’re pretty useless in terms of troubleshooting. Just by telling a friend they should try a restaurant, that friend will consider if we have similar taste in restaurants, if I tend to order similar things, if I make more or less healthy choices than they do, how much I might feel is reasonable to spend on a night out for dinner, if I’ve steered them wrong, and however many dozen other factors. A restaurant marketing team might want to learn and understand each one of those things, but even if I was going to sit through an hour long survey, we just aren’t good at quantizing how we feel about any of those things into absolute values. And that’s before all the bs. Anything but all 5s is a failure, leaving the worst scores possible because someone was rude, etc. A marketing person who must insist they understand the consumer, no matter how unrealistic that is, to keep their job. A department head that’s never gonna take responsibility for bad performance.

So we’ll submit to horrendously inefficient processes to truncate these incredibly complex ideas we’re able to perceive and communicate down to bits that represent little, if any, of the source to have a measurable data point because we know it survives communication and to some extent helps us navigate through our own BS. I would categorized the chip talked about in this video as ASIC (Application Specific Integrated Circuit). It's a kind of IC that performs a very specific task very efficiently, but only able to perform that task. This kind of chips are getting increasingly popular as the demand for computing power increases, and they are possibly the way of how computing done in the future. 

While analog technologies are cool, they are imprecise, and that could be a major problem as the error could have built up if the input of the next computation depends on the result of pervious computation (a.k.a., an iterative algorithm). Interesting enough, digital computer has this problem as well. As floating point numbers with fixed width can only represents a finite number of states, they are not good at representing real numbers (think of performing multiplication on 2 real number with 100 decimal places together, the computer is unlikely to get the exact number with 200 decimal places). And there is whole area of study in applied mathematics about numeric algorithms to mitigate these kinds of issues. For analog computer, the degradation of signal is mostly due to physics, and there is not much research regarding the mitigation of them, if we can do anything about them at all.

The example given for why analog computers are energy efficient it strange to me. That circuit isn't very energy efficient at all because in order to maintain the output at the desired value, it has to continuously draw current, proportional to the strength of the output signal. Whereas an equivalent digital circuit can store a result in a memory register while consuming minimal current and therefore power. Another problem with analog circuits such as that, is although it uses fewer components, the size of components often needs to be relatively large compared to digital transistors, and these larger components use more power.

...so are there like no computer scientists in the comment section? Because every single thing Veritasium said in the first 3 minutes wasn't true. A transistor is fundamentally a switch. The "bits" in digital computing are an abstracted way of referring to low and high voltage. So his description of an analog computer is just a very simplified digital computer.
His "analog" computer is just an example of how digital computing got its start. Where the transistors were large switches which controlled the voltage inputs. His statement that to add two 8 bit numbers you need around 50 transisters is misleading. In computing, arithmetic is done via an ALU circuit pattern. And while modern ones use a fair amount of transistors that's only because modern computers have built in error correction. If all you want is to add two numbers and you don't care about any of the bells and whistles it takes a fraction of the circuit components to do that. Also, computers are exceedingly efficient at specifically this. So him saying analog computers would be better at this task is disingenuous.
The real difference between an "analog" and digital computer is the analog computer does not have the abstraction layers a digital computer does. No assembly language, machine language, or higher order programming languages.
I'm also pretty dubious on the utility of those analog computer chips. Frankly the only thing they have over a digital chip was lower power consumption. So for the extremely specific use case of a neural net machine learning application done at a very large scale for the least amount of money in components, it makes sense. For anything else, no. There's a reason analog computing was replaced.

Pure nonsense. Analog computers are NOT fast - they are limited by the bandwidths and settling times of their operational amplifiers, which are far slower than the digital arithemetic processors that are used to solve the same problems digitally. They are NOT "incredibly powerful" - there has to be a separate circuit for each element in the problem, each term of the differential equation being solved. Analog computer circuits can't multitask; once you've used up all of the circuits, you can't simulate anything more complex. You can only expand the problem by adding more circuits. Modern digital simulations can easily solve the problems that the toy he is demonstrating can, and CAN display these in real time as well. But as soon as you add one more term to the equation, the digital simulation slows down ever so slightly (as a factor of how much the complexity has increased), while the analog system simply cannot continue. And then there's repeatability. The digital simulation can be repeated, and will produce exactly the same results again. This is just not possible with analog computers. With analog computers, there are errors introduced by electrical noise in the components, and changes in the circuit characteristics with temperature. These make it difficult to achieve even a 0.1% accuracy and repeatability. He mentions 1% in the video, which is what low-cost analog is good for. In contrast, the accuracy of a 64-bit arithmetic unit is two parts in 10^-19, which is less than one part per million million million. And absolutely repeatable.

And then he talks about power, and makes an implied connection between the number of transistors and the power required. This isn't even close to correct. The size of transistors used in microprocessors, and their power requirement per transistor, is microscopic compared with that of the transistors required by analog computers to achieve even their limited capabilities.

Then he moves on to neural nets (e.g., the Perceptron). Again, MUCH easier to implement digitally than with analog circuits. In fact, the weighted sum example he gives is a perfect case to apply a GPU to. And digital circuitry scales down in size (and power) much better than does analog.

Oh! Wait a moment! You know how figures never lie, but liars always figure? The chart he shows for the improvement over time of neural nets over time has a huge red flag: the chart does not start its vertical axis at zero. This is a common way of skewing data, because it makes changes near the bottom of the chart look more significant than they are. BAD science. And his assertion that analog circuits can be scaled up to the level needed for this sort of neural net is misguided at best. As I said, you can't get the same kind of analog performance out of a nanometer-scale transistor that you can in a digital application. The notion that you can get an accurate analog multiplication out of a flash memory cell is just fantasy. And sure, you can afford some loss of accuracy in neural nets, but let's not pretend that you get the kind of accuracy the digital net can out of these.

A key point flew by kind of quickly at 18:10. The analog computing guy pointed out that you would still use traditional hardware for training the network (i.e., figuring out the weights for each connection that give the best results). But then once you've done that and you were ready to deploy it (say, to ship a bunch of products that use that trained model), that's when they'd use their analog chip which could be set at the factory to whatever weights you'd found worked the best.

So, they're definitely envisioning this as a marriage of analog and digital, not as analog being better than digital.

These re-purposed flash-memory cells sound a lot like another neural-network technique I read about years ago. It was using regular old RAM chips to store the network. The address lines of the chip served as the inputs to the neuron and the stored value as the neuron's activation for that combination of inputs. When training, you just write in a new value, and when running, you read it out. Sure, it's strictly binary, but it is pretty similar. You could implement it in software with a bunch of lookup tables. The catch is the memory requirements would be quite high. A 16-input neuron would need 64kbit of memory. A network of a million such neurons would need around 8GB of memory, PLUS additional memory to handle all the information about how they're connected.

That's not how you do analog multiplication, or rather it'd be an extremely limited way to do it, to the point of uselessness. True analog multiplication done with circuits like the Gilbert Cell or I think some analog devices chips do it with particular arrangements of log and anti-log amplifiers. You're also doing it with any mixer circuit like those used for amplitude modulation such as the diode ring mixer. Analog devices app notes like MT-079 are an excellent resource for learning about this kind of stuff.

Socionics came from cybernetics originally. Socionics is a system of personality types and their interactions. They have 'information elements,' the types of information that exist out there in the world. I myself use 'introverted sensing,' and so I think about things like how would you program a computer to do that. Some aspects of introverted sensing include how objects interact with each other, and I like to think of the Sesame Street song, sung by Grover, 'Over, Under, Around, and Through.' Can you teach a computer about those interactions, those prepositions? You don't have to teach it what the objects are, you only have to teach it that some sort of object is there, which means, teach it topology. There is some blob-shaped thing, which is smaller than the background image. If the blob-shaped thing includes a bunch of other objects inside it, then it's the background. How do the objects interact with the other objects? Knowing what the objects are isn't important, just distinguishing between background and object is important, and then seeing how they interact is important. In humans, introverted sensing is used for something like, for example, skiing. You have to ski down the hill, avoid crashing into a tree, avoid crashing into other skiers, avoid interacting with slippery ice, try to interact with snow that has the desired texture, avoid going over moguls. A racecar driver also has to use this. It doesn't matter so much if you can tell the difference between a Ford and a Honda, all that matters is that you avoid bumping into the object, so that means, you have to understand how objects interact with other objects, and how they interact with the background image. Where is one object with respect to another object?

The biggest issue really has to do with design. Maybe you should get a degree in EE before posting this nonsense. The entire reason why digital design is there is precisely because we don't need to deal with the much stricter standards needed for analog design where very precise tolerances are needed. If you only need to deal with 2 Voltages (HIGH and LOW), the transistor characteristics are less of a factor and only need to operate within the respective envelopes (which are pretty large mind you) in order to be used. Furthermore other things (like wire inductance, resistance and capacitance) need to be strictly characterized in order to design your circuit. Transistors characteristics also need to be very strictly measured as gate capacitance and leakage current all need to be strictly characterized in order to use it as an analog computer.

Every single EE student is taught about the reasons we learn to design digital circuits in our digital circuits classes. Of course it would be preferable if we could use multiple bits per transistor. Just using 4 bits per transistor would shrink designs radically and decrease costs radically. However, in order to do so would require cost prohibitive increases in manufacturing as almost every nanowire and transistor would need to meet precise specifications, and would also be highly imprecise as there would be enough perturbance due to natural factors (like temperature increases, humidity and radiation loads) where the systems would be mostly unreliable.

For anyone else, let the engineers working on your chips do their jobs. If there was a better way of doing it, they would have clearly done so as the cost implications would be massive. The reasons chips are built the way they are is so they can remain robust and produce results reliably. As someone with a degree in electrical engineering, I find the implications of this video frankly appalling. If you're interested further in this subject, Digital Design and Computer Architecture by Sarah Harris is a good book to pick up.

Neurons may be "digital" if you only look at them as "fired"/"Did not fire", but neurons are not absolutely 1/0. You can have a slight firing like a hint, a premonition, a doubt, a whim, or a really hard fire like irreversible trauma, psicosis, etc. That's why it's not so easy for us at this point to replicate real human intelligence, because we still have no complete knowledge of how the human brain works in its deepest basic level. What we see is the output of the processing, but not how the processing itself is done, much less controlled. In the future what we will have is the knowledge of how to replicate the human thinking PLUS the amazing speed and accuracy of the computer. We could potentially end up with machines capable of thinking and processing in ways that even we biological humans could not dream of.... And then machines will become sentient and we will be doomed. :-)

Analog computers don't compute anything. They are are just a different implementation of the mathematical model of some phenomenon and its voltage output is driven by its designed physical properties. The implementation involves resistors, capacitors and inductance in combination with operational amplifiers. Early guitar effects are analog computers with the guitar connected to it's input and speakers on the output. The same way we don't say the falling apple is calculating it's position and speed.

What seems obvious to me is not to have one or the other, but a computer or system that integrates both. Indeed, that seems to be what the Mythic AI guys alluded to, and indeed look to have built what is an add-in card that is the analog computer, that the digital computer + software calls upon when needed. After all, if an analog computer is limited in its abilities and scope, then it makes sense for it to simply be a component that fulfills that particular function, no different to, say, a GPU, a hard drive, a sound card, a keyboard, a camera, etc. Taking a graphics card / GPU for example.. Sure, your CPU could render those graphics, but the performance will suck. So you offload specific tasks to that dedicated, purpose built hardware. So maybe it may end up being made as simple as plugging in your Analog AI device, pointing your software to it, and voila - your AI performance is 1000x better.

In addition to Analog, what if the way we create Perceptron is wrong too? After all, our brain is the one creating the Perceptron from the start, with not only 8 layers, but thousands or millions and with the ability to judge its own mistakes. Why is it still programers who setup the Perceptron layers and tell it whether it's a correct answer or not, instead of the program itself. The very key to machine learning is the automatic judgment of an answer, not the answer itself. IA nowadays is "satisfying" with one Perceptron, but think about it, your brain has many of them. Aren't you ever about to say something and you think twice before actually speaking? "Rerunning" this thoughts into a deeper Perceptron than the fast and efficient (but inexact) one you just ran? As if you had a "creative brain" that allow mistakes (aka "creations", some good ones, some bad ones) but caught up by a second module of judgment, making the "creative answers" entering your deeper brain that is more energy costing but very much exact. Finally, your judgment module and the creative brain are corrected by the deeper brain itself as a complete cycle maximizing the performance at lower energy cost and faster brain. That is why you can always be better and faster at anything you do for a long time, you just run this cycle longer and it becomes more pleasant because the efficiency of your action compared to the energy you have to put in has a better ratio. (Just random thoughts of a software engineer 🤔)

First, I think the current title ("We're building Computers Wrong") crosses the line into 'clickbait' territory. Does the video show that we're building computers wrong? No, it shows how certain tasks can be performed more efficiently by using a fundamentally different computing approach. Those are not the same thing at all.
Second, this was a very interesting video and gave a great explanation for how neural networks function.
Finally, I think neuromorphic computing should have been at least mentioned, as it is intended for precisely the kinds of tasks that were being discussed here.

Normally I love your stuff, but this was a bad video. It incorrectly sets up a strawman premise that "digital" refers only to general-purpose processing and "analog" is the only way to design task-specific processes. It completely ignores the Application-Specific Integrated Circuit (ASIC) and the Field Programmable Gate Array (FPGA) as energy efficient and performant ways to tailor digital processors for specific tasks. Even down to this strawman being a part of the clickbait title. You're better than this!

It also lays a contradictory premise that accuracy is not needed, but then goes on to explain how difficult it is to train a recognition system on a dataset, requiring tweaking highly specific weights for improving the correctness, which would not be possible with inaccurate calculations. With absolutely no effort to explain how these two contradictory problems are in any way resolved.

Is the Mythic product review in the end neat? Sure. It's a novel approach. I don't know how long those chips will last as flash memory has a limited number of cycles, but it's still an inspired approach to a problem. That doesn't justify the entire groundwork of crap this video was beforehand. It would have been far better to just explain why the matrix calculations are an important part of the process and how that applies to Mythic's use-case, and then compare the Mythic product(s) to other products that have used different approaches.

I've had the idea for awhile now to create an ASIC for motherboards which automatically overclock RAM to its highest potential in a given bios. After spending a few years overclocking RAM and studying AMD overclocking guidelines, you need nearly 100% accuracy to have stable RAM, and even a slight deviation can crash modern benchmark software like Prime95. The gold standard is to not have a single RAM error in Prime95 for a few days of nonstop operation.

You could sell gaming motherboards for more of a premium if you developed such an analog neural chip, and would have to train it with correct voltages, timings, CPU Speeds (infinity fabric speeds) and temperatures. The goal would be to buy any nice (nice being Samsung or maybe Hynix Trident-Z) of any speed, say, 3000 MHz such as mine, and very quickly acquire a 4200 MHz stable overclock with little to no fuss, greatly increasing Ryzen processing power. Or, even stabilizing/optimizing some poorly integrated XMP/DOCP settings/timings, which are generally MOSTLY correct but not perfectly optimal due to the vast number of CPUs in existence.

In the field of neuromorphic computing there are also other approaches. For example modeling the actual electrical characteristics of neurons and synapses with analog ICs. One practical implemantion of this can be found in the BrainScales project which implements so called spiking neural networks. This machine works similar to actual neurons and synapses but in a scaled up voltage domain and with a scaled down time constant (larger voltages and way faster than biological neurons). With this comes the challange of the interface. It must be really really fast to keep up with the "computation".
Despite being very energy efficient another problem is that in the analog domain analyzability is restricted because you would never be able to track the whole behavior of the circuit.
Analog circuits are also highly dependent on variations in the silicon (doping, substrate,...) across the same and/or multiple chips which can cause non-reproducable results.

One thing which is an important distinction, which Derek only touched briefly upon, is that for the AI network the multiply accumulate operation is an approximation. So when a bit of noise is introduced (either by reducing the bit precision of digital operations or by analog introduced variation), the network will likely still function well enough to do its job.

This is unlike digital circuits where even a single bit flip in a result can spell disaster for the whole system.

So I doubt that analog is the new king of computation over digital binary logic in all fields. However in the world of AI, it makes total sense to approximate a noisy analog computation using noisy analog circuits (when using the AI) - or their digital equivilent like Tesla does in their vision ASICs.

The irony is that as far as I am aware, the training still requires classical digital logic to update the weights.

One point to keep in mind is that Neural networks, despite their name, have virtually nothing to do with the neurons in the human brain. Neural networks by far prioritise end results over biological consistency/feasibility.

By far, the major downside of analogue computing, why it could never be a serious contender to neural networks, and why it is highly unlikely the human brain relies on it in any significant manner, is that it is hugely inefficient at encoding information. Take the 8 bit number system, you can encode a total of 2^8 distinguishing symbols; and that is done using only 8 base components. Let's represent these base components as marbles. So the digital encoding needs at most 8 marbles to encode 256 numbers. On the other hand, in order to encode such a range of number in an analogue system, you need 256 marbles. In short, analogue computer sizes scale linearly with the amount of information they can encode, digital computer sizes scale logarithmically.

neural nets need to be able to encode a ridiculous amount of information. Switching them to analogue based computers would mean them becoming exponentially larger.

My background is a mix of software and hardware engineering, but I expect analog computation to stay fairly niche for the foreseeable future. Digital is just too good of a fit for the majority of our simple and mostly mechanical needs, and most computer engineering jobs don't require the types of advanced mathematical skills needed for analog systems. In the digital world, any system can be built from just NAND and NOR gates, built upon boolean algebra and layered with enough abstractions to enable us to do very useful things.

That being said, we definitely need analog computing techniques too and rely on them heavily for communications systems. I think the way we "are building computers wrong" is by taking that one size fits all approach. The kind of analog computing work you highlighted is incredibly impressive, but is heavily academic and requires greater math skills than most of us have on the commercial side.

Additionally, I think we will see some revolutionary ideas come about on the digital side too. I think what we need to push THAT forward is an open source boom in hardware similar to what open source did for software in the 90s. My expectation is that as Moore's Law and Von Neumann architecture hits its ceiling, we'll be moving into more creative digital approaches as we can't just rely on next year's computers being cheaper and faster. My bet is on technology like FPGAs that enable software defined hardware, but most of that ecosystem is currently too focused on high end problems (that may be better solved with analog!) and not on enabling use for normal developers.

Analog computers will take off when we start using biologic computers. Once you can grow AI that have already learned most of what it needs to before it gets deployed, that is what is going to change humanity into something new.

I went through engineering school in the 1970s, and they still taught us to program analog computers.  It was a great way to learn the ins and outs of classical control theory.  It was a holdover from the 1950s art of aircraft control system design, which NASA had perfected, then replaced with digital control system design.  But during the transition from all analog to pure digital, NASA (specifically the Dryden [now Armstrong] Flight Research Center) made use of hybrid computers:  combining the features of analog and digital computers.  I've often wondered about whether this pairing would in some way allow us to build computers capable of solving the Navier-Stokes equations at fine enough mesh sizes to really tackle the problem of turbulence.  I was blown away by the computation rate of that single, 3 watt chip.  One thing analog computers don't do is differentiation - solving "differential equations" on an analog computer actually consists of casting the equations in integral form, then solving them.  Trying to take a derivative on an analog computer, while possible from an electrical schematic standpoint, winds up amplifying noise so rapidly that the solution blows up.  If digital circuits did the differentiating, that problem might be eliminated (especially with the breathtaking performance of digital filters in suppressing circuit noise).  The chip design for something like that would be amazing!

I've been in computing a long time and there have always been people trying to get around the von Neuman bottleneck. In some sense, we've done that by making computing devices ubiquitous. Most of the tasks we want computers to do are now easily done by them, but we keep coming up with new tasks.

There's room for this stuff, I think. It isn't going to take over, though. The reason that digital has taken over is fidelity. The one-thousandth generation copy of a digital signal is highly likely to be identical to the first-generation. This is not the case with analog. And most of the stuff we do with computing needs that fidelity. But you're right, the AI applications don't, really.

Couple things to point out:

1) The biological neuron analogy is crude and vague at best. Neurons in the human brain have far more connections, and said connections are far more complex. There are feedback loops, and research has even shown that there is way more going on than just the neurons "firing", right down to tiny chemical reactions happening throughout the cells, which all influence the "output". In short, ANNs are very loosely based on any biological structure, and their shortcomings clearly reflect that. And while we made a lot of advancements, it is still an open question whether we can go further, or if we're just optimizing a few extra percents on a plateau.

2) Generally speaking, when discussing AI, one must keep in mind that underneath all the fancy tech buzzwords, what they are doing is simply data association. They are essentially giant bags of database entries that say things like "when you see this pattern of pixels, it's 57% likely to be a dog". This is putting it very crudely, of course, but the point is that they don't do anything magical, and certainly not anything analogous to "thinking", not any more than when cruise control adjusts the throttle based on the speed of the car. It just seems like it's "intelligence" because it performs tasks that are (or at least look like) the kind of thing humans do.

It was refreshing to hear the researcher in the video mention something like a detector on an assembly line. This is an underrated role for such systems, i.e optimizing performance in controlled environments. Machines work best in environments that humans can design for specific tasks. The "natural world" is far too noisy and uneven, and you need far more effort to make a machine work reliably in it.

3) The ImageNet achievements, while impressive, also ended up creating an overly optimistic attitude that has led to quite a few harsh reality checks (bordering on another "AI winter"). As it turns out, simply figuring out labels for images is a relatively easy task, and even that took decades to improve to this extent. Once you go beyond that level, you need exponentially more data, and even the tiniest error rate can lead to critical failures. The problem these days is that a lot of researchers and big companies can just brute force a better ImageNet score and claim that they made "improvements", when in reality the networks are now just "better at ImageNet" (i.e overly specialized on a task that isn't directly useful in any real-life application).

4) Related to 3), the difference between 96% and 99% confidence that an image is a chicken is anything but trivial. And let's not even get into adversarial problems, where an image that is actually just a seemingly random mess of pixels is also classified by the network with 99% confidence as "a chicken". Indeed, when all you're doing is just assigning labels to images, this isn't a huge issue, but in any critical system where you must not make mistakes, it's a much greater issue. And this becomes even worse when those few percents of error are a symptom of bigger flaws under the hood.

5) The power consumption of training neural networks cannot be overstated, and I am very glad Derek made it one of the key points of his video. This is another domain in which biological neurons humiliate computer science, as our brains can perform countless operations using a fraction of a fraction of the power of computers attempting to do the same tasks. With that in mind, advancements such as the analog matrix multiplication chips are very welcome indeed.

Probably worth pointing out that it's not a (pardon the pun) binary choice. Both analog and digital components would have their roles, with the former providing speed and simplicity, while the latter offers reliability and ease of programming. The key is combining the two in the same system, assigning tasks to the components that are best suited for them.

The problem with this system of computing is that interference is a huge factor. When you only test to see if there is voltage or not then you  don't need to worry about interference. But when you get into building systems that use varying voltages say 0v 0.5v 1v then you need to worry about interference, and the more numbers you add the greater this factors into being an issue. Interference could come in the form of microwaves, radiation, mechanical vibration (think fans cooling off a server rack,) and the list drags on as almost anything can cause interference. That ostiliscope used in the example is an expensive piece of equipment that minimizes interference, but the cost is far higher than with a binary number system.

ML researcher here. The issues Derek mentions at 13:40 could use some re examination. And by some I mean a lot.
1. The entire schtick with "neural nets consume a lot of energy" is overblown by AI Ethics people, and I hate that it is getting mainstream because influencers pick up on the congnitively simple argument. Training a billion parameter model is no more expensive than it is to host content on any social media platforms. We don't worry about energy consumption when watching this video do we?

2. This is the only argument that made sense to me, because moving tensors to and from memory is the bottleneck for ML training. While the effects are negligible at smaller models, when you're training models hundreds of billions of parameters the effect is significant enough to warrant years of research in improving communication hardware. See: NVLink, NVSwitch, Infiniband. I don't know how much more performance can be hypothetically squeezed out of a DGX-A100 if we quadrupled it's bandwidth magically.

3. Moore's law: another bait. Supposedly the Moore's law has been "dying" for at least two decades now. We are still at 7nm architectures when working with hardware specialized for neural net training. We can go all the way down to 3nm, maybe even 1nm. So there's still a ways to go. Secondly, while Moore's original law was pertaining to the number of transistors on an IC, it is in no way limiting the fact that we can keep squeezing more compute per square mm out of a chip. 3D architectures and using electromagnetic waves instead of electrons for operations are avenues that will practically remove any computational barriers for the next couple of decades. Even now, while the number of transistors may closely follow Moore's law of doubling every two years, compute possible from a chip exceeds Moore's law significantly. And ultimately, the only thing we care about is compute, not pushing the transistors into ever tinier spaces. It just so happens that doing the latter achieves the former. Designing better algorithms for matrix multiplication for example could make the current chips usable for the next few years.

You're making a lot of claims that are patently false. Without understanding computer architecture, you are taking bits and pieces of information from multiple sources and piecing together a false narrative.

Most importantly, you don't need an analog computer for either (1) a solution to the Von Neumann bottleneck, or (2) a lot of computation happening in parallel. Custom built digital CPUs for neural network training, such as Google TPUs, don't have the bottleneck problem and perform a lot of computations in a single clock cycle (like a huge lot.)

Also, transistors are not the size of atoms. When you see the label 7nm on a chip, that actually does not correspond to any feature size (a while back it used to mean something ...). Transistors are still about 20nm in size, with poly-Si having a lattice constant of roughly half a nm (though of course, this does strengthen the argument that Moore's law is over).

Yes, there are some significant advantages (and disadvantages) to analog computing, and I honestly wish the startups best of luck! The issue is your narrative.

In 1957 when I was in Jr. High school, I made the honest mistake of trying to build a digital computer, using the simple analog resistor multiplication device shown in a "General Electric Progress Poster" on the wall of our electronics shop class, one of the very first taught in a Jr. High. I added pushbuttons and individual wires for two sets of ten adjustable clips, replacing the single wire and clip that was moved along each of two resistive wires adjacent to a meter stick shown in the poster. I described this for the Science Fair project I entered as a "Digital Computer". My thinking was that the pushbuttons were activated with the digits at the end of our arms.
Although other students at other schools had entered a simple copy of the poster illustration, mine won that year's blue ribbon for the category. A lot of work, late into the night went into overcoming the inaccuracy of the resultant reading of the needle on the large, (analog) milliammeter that the poster recommended for student copies. Each of my clips would alter the total resistance of each leg, and the one rheostat used for balance calibration (also found on every analog ohmmeter in those days) so that the multiplied result of two buttons pushed was only very approximately correct. It would appear though that I was 65 years ahead of our time... all by accident of ignorance.

Buried in this excellent video are some important ideas from information theory.   In essence, the more precisely a model can describe a set of training data, the greater the risk of failure when making a prediction that goes outside that set.   (It's why a model that fits all past football games can, and often does, fail spectacularly when predicting future games.)  If you use a huge data set, you are really only improving matters for things that are implicitly within that set.  This can be, of course, super-useful, but it's easy to lose sight of the inherent limitations.  So here's where analog comes in.  The uncertainties within analog can, in theory, help loosen the model up enough to make predictions outside the set more reliable.  So there's some theoretical reason to support analog computers as well.

There is this cool thing called reservoir computing which considers harnessing the dynamics of complex physical systems for machine learning tasks. Basically if the dynamics of the system becomes some function of a signal that is driving it then you can post process its response to carry out all sort of tasks such as speech recognition or chaotic time series prediction. Some folks are even considering quantum systems for this, which is called quantum reservoir computing (not to be confused with its cousin, quantum computing).

Will anolog computer advances bring true autonomous AI? Well, yes and no. Analog is surely a step into the right direction for various reasons mentioned in the video, but we will never get to true intelligence solely by that. In my opinion this is because we are trying to skip the most important step in the process.
It all boils down to the question of "Why do we think like we do?". Our thinking capabilities have clear purpose in that they make living easier. If we solely focus on the question "how do we think?" and try to replicate this process in a machine, it will still lack the most important component of true intelligence: Purpose.
Therefore I believe projects like creating a digital human brain are doomed by default. We should not try to create Intelligence directly in the digital space, but instead should try to create digital life. Life is the purpose that made us develop Intelligence, and a highly intelligent species will naturally emerge over time, as understanding something will always yield the best solutions to a problem. However without life there are no "problems" only questions you train a machine to solve. A machine like this could never doubt its own solution to a question, it needs to be told that by a source from the outside that it is wrong - so it would never really be able to "learn from mistakes" - which is what we call intelligence.

Tl;dr: Don't create artificial intelligence, create artificial life. Life is purpose and purpose breeds true intelligence.

As someone who works with electronics and have studied computer architecture design for over a decade, this video is a bit abhorrent in some areas....
First off, to add two 8 bit numbers, one needs more than 50 transistors. 200-250 would be more accurate, but if one also wants look ahead carry for faster calculations, then 300-400 is more correct.

Secondly, multiplying numbers can be done in a multitude of different ways.
Bit shifting and conditional additions is the easiest, and here we can either prioritize transistor count, or performance. Ie, doing it less or more parallel. (For multiplying two 8 bit numbers, we can either use one 8 bit adder, or eight 8 bit adders to form an array.)

Then we have the Von Neumann bottleneck....
This isn't always a bottleneck, nor is it always applicable. Architectures like X86, ARM and so forth do have a multitude of ways to greatly reduce the requirement for memory bandwidth. Computer architectures are generally designed with the concept of programming loops in mind. Different aspects of a program are cyclic to different degrees, through Registers and Cache we can negate the need to go out to main memory for a majority of our operations.

However, certain applications dealing with large datasets where only minor computations are required on each data point, then we can stumble into the "Von Neumann bottleneck" or rather a memory bandwidth bottleneck (no need to credit Von Neumann for this). AI, image/video editing, particle physics, and a few other applications tends to require more memory bandwidth than most typical applications.

Then we have miniaturization of transistors.
We aren't even remotely close to transistors the size of an atom. Just because semiconductor manufacturers calls their nodes "3nm" doesn't mean that the transistors they build are 3nm large. In fact, the smallest feature on these transistors are about 20nm, and the transistor itself is a good few times larger than that. Ie, the transistors are still hundreds of atoms wide.

And in regards to computing.
AI and neural networks are "interesting". They are useful for some applications, but are generally over applied outside of what they are actually good at.
I know of a lot of programmers that frankly turn to AI/NN for simpler logical tasks that they could have just written a few lines of code to do, instead of using a neural network that consumes a lot more resources while being slower at the job... (Though, programmers are getting less good at actually programming as school courses focuses more on AI/NN instead of how to break down complex tasks into smaller more manageable chunks that one can then express as logical statements. Training an AI/NN isn't programming, it is just randomly adjusting an array of values and picking the one that performed the best in some test and then reiterating over and over and over... A child can do this.)

The vast majority of computing tasks requires fairly basic logic and not that much number crunching either.
Though, a lot of modern programming habits tends to follow fairly inefficient approaches, like storing numbers as strings, running high level code in interpreters and using an excessive amount of floating point and arbitrarily large variables to hold generally small values. Not to mention an overreliance on bloated libraries.

AI/NN isn't applicable for a lot of computing tasks. And even for a lot of stuff where AI/NN are applicable, they have the downside of being hard to train, and having unknown behavior in situations outside their training, and this needs to be taken into consideration for a lot of applications. Then there is the unforeseen consequences of the AI/NN's decisions, so for some applications a risk analysis should be conducted, and a testing phase in a controlled environment. (even if it is something as simple as a chat bot for customer service handling returns.)

Frankly in my own opinion. AI/NN are in general overhyped. Certain things they are good at, the vast majority of computing tasks they are abhorrent at...

16:38 — This is a very clever idea, but I’m surprised they can get anywhere near enough precision using this adaptation of Flash bit cells.

A flash bit cell (a form of EEPROM bit cell) is a slightly modified MOSFET, which is exactly a voltage-controlled resistor. As you pointed out, the gate is made floating on a flash bit cell, and its voltage is set by tunneling electrons or “holes” into that insulated gate.

The problem though is that this tunneling mechanism is very process-dependent. That is, each chip or each bit cell on a single chip, tends to have different resistances. It’s designed to be all-or-nothing digital, and not to produce a precisely-calibrated analog value.

Also, the sense amplifiers that read off the bit-cell values are not designed as analog-to-digital converters, but instead quantize to a digital one or zero. So, they presumably can’t use off-the-shelf flash for this.

Still, it’s a cool idea!

Good video but the conclusion is a bit unfortunate.
"..in that thinking takes place everywhere, all at once." this is not necessarily analog.
There is a field of asynchronous digital circuits, these are digital circuits without a clock signal.
Thing get messy quickly without a clock and so most digital systems rely on a clock to keep everything in sync.
And even with a clock you could argue that parallel computing happens 'everywhere' and 'all at once'.
Analog just means that the signal is not discretized but a continuous function in time.

In that sense the analogy becomes messy, because every practical implementation of a digital circuit happens in the analog domain: real voltages/currents take time to rise and fall.
We just see them as being binary but we have to be careful and use things like Schmitt triggering to view the analog signal as digital.

All of this doesn't take away that 'analog computing' where the 'real analog signals' are viewed directly as 'the information' and not just as 'a means to carry digital information' is very interesting and has potential to replace some of the current digital computing paradigms.

This idea is quite similar to the paradigm shift that was bit shift math for 3D games back in the 90s before 3D graphics was accelerated through hardware. We think computers are fast, but they are fast like a highway clogged with heavy traffic. One accident and the whole thing screeches to a halt. Also, like you said, with bottlenecks like the bus, the processor is usually just waiting for data to move around.
This became a massive problem back in the 90s with 3D games, because the math involved crushed computers at the time. For many of the games, if the math was done right, you would probably get one frame over the course of several seconds rather than the 60+ demanded for nowadays. Also, the resolution was 320x240 for quite a while. I don't think watches are even restricted to that today.
So, the programmers had to find ways around the computer's math bottlenecks. One way, which was done by famous games like Doom, was to make 2.5D games. First, you render a back image of the ceiling and the floor merging off into infinity. They were never 3D. Then, instead of drawing 3D, you drew 2D images with depth modifiers, which would simply shrink x and y coordinates the further they were supposed to be away from the screen. Characters were Sprites just like in Mario, but they were shrank according to the distance modifier, so it would appear like they were further away.
To get real 3D though, some smart programmers used bit shifting math. Math operations are very expensive computationally, requiring a large number of clock cycles at the time. But, if you shifted a register, it took one clock cycle. If you shifted a bit to the left, you multiplied it by two. So, 001 became 010, and 1 became 2. The 010 became 100, so 2 became 4. The same is said of shifting to the right, you divided by 2.
So, with a bit of loss in precision, you could multiply and divide in just a few clock cycles instead of hundreds. Add in having the computer store results of pretty much every sin and cosine result in a look up table and you had functional and fast 3D engines that worked well enough for games.

Our neurons might be "digital" when it comes to action potentials and firing either a 0 or a 1. But the action potentials "collected" by the neuron are affected by analog noise all around the cells which does affect the result, wither 0 or 1. The analog noise is basically all the other stuff floating around in the brain, various substances, hormones, proteins, waste products of metabolism. They all constitue a constant and ever changing, chaotic noise. The ultimate computer is thus neither a digital one nor an analog one. It is a combination of both. The output is "digital" on each "step", but the computing is "analog", because it is affected unpredictably by analog noise, so one identical digital input will not yield the same output. Multiply this by many layers and you will need correction mechanisms, which undoubtly our brains have. These correction mechanisms work on the same principle of digital-analog computing.

"Our brains are digital, in that a neuron either fires or it doesn't, but they're also analog, in that thinking takes place everywhere, all at once."

Two problems here: first, our brains are NOT digital. Each neuron has an action potential, which is truly analog, and firing of neurons cause a short period of inactivity (refractory period) which is also dependent on the much analog charge. This affects the "rate of fire" and thus frequency response of neurons.

Second, "computation taking place everywhere all at once" is totally possible with digital, and is indeed what makes GPUs good at such computations. This is called parallelism, and it's not unique to analog or digital.

In this video the state of computational performance for training and infering of ai models is only represented by GPUs, which is a quite widespread way to do it, but Tensor Processing units (TPU's) are also available and designed for these kinds of operations.
They can be found in flagship phones and have also made their way into modern Graphics cards and dedicated PCI-e cards.

Another promising route for AI is quantum computing, but at this point it is only a potential application.

You did not mention the non-linear activation function. Based on your explanation, one viewer with some linear algebra knowledge would say that if a dense layer (perceptron) is just a matrix multiplication then multiple dense layers (multi layer perceptron) is just a sequence of matrix multiplications. Since any two consecutive matrix multiplications (two linear transformations) can be substituted by one single matrix multiplication (one linear transformation), why to use multiple layers? Furthermore, matrices can describe only linear transformations, how the hell can such a thing approximate non-linear functions?
The solution is: there is always a non-linear transformation called activation after each matrix multiplication. In the simplest case, this is just a relu function (f(x) = x if x>0, 0 otherwise), or something like sigmoid or so. This is an essential part, which would make someone with some math knowledge think that what you were speaking about is a nonsense.

All the assumptions in this video have been known to information technology industry for years, i.e digital circuitry is excellent for generic use, however if you need performance you must use application-specific circuitry. For example, a form of "analog" circuitry exists in all network switches in the form of ASIC (Application-specific integrated circuit) components. The advantages of these components are their superior processing speed, compared to "digital" components, however these cannot be reprogrammed on the fly, e.g. in case of a bug. A middle-tier exists in the form of FPGAs (Field programmable gate array) that combines the versatility of digital components and the performance of analog, however the main drawback is the very high cost. So this is all known and have been applied in industry for years.

You said our brain is digital...this is false. You also stated that the neurons are either on or off all at once...this is also false. It takes time for the signal to propagate down the axon, there are gaps called "nodes of ranvier" that create a timing function to the signal, which allows not only signals in space but time as well (and my hypothesis is that this allows for "forward thinking" abilities of "what if" scenarios in training). It also creates a field, which has a biological aspect in how neurons move and interact....which can cause dampening of the signal in transit, resulting in less chemical transfer at the axon terminals to the dendrites. This has the effect of analog stepping, not to mention fluid sweeping which can dilute the signal further. There are a dozen of other mechanisms that happen that suggests that neurons are more like opamps than just a simple transistor.

Within 2 years I was doing an apprenticeship as an electrician at Cattle Creek Sugar Mill with Jim Barbat (Dad) and a brilliant chap, John Knight, a digital whizz kid, writing software using Boolean Algebra for the new digital programmable logic controllers used for factory automation. Integrating the analogue signals from the existing equipment with the new digital equipment was a challenge at the time, a steep learning curve.
I occasionally write machine code for equipment nowdays that needs to be run reliably and safely using digital programmable logic controllers, however, I think about it in an 'Analogue way', an input, op-amp, a digital or a analogue output signal.
I recall recently the excitement regarding the 'Memristor', the 4th electrical element, the first 3 being resistance, capacitance and inductance..

Apart from the lack of computing power we had one other major issue with deep (as in a lot of layers) artificial neutral networks: the vanishing gradient problem.

This is essentially what GoogLeNet and ResNet tackle to achieve significant improvement compared to the AlexNet (which was just huge)

What it boils down to essentially is that the more layers you have, the harder it is to significantly adjust inner weights using the backpropagation algorithm. You only get any significant gradient within the last few layers, but only the initial layers convey any meaningful data (when the network is still untrained). Everything else is just a homogenous soup of averaged activations (because the weights are still random)

I remember some short tale from Asimov's I robot, where he described a robot taking a particular "change of mind" as the result of a build up of a "voltage value" or "potential"... I can't really remember but the idea I got was that the robot had one idea at first, then it was presented with a conflicting idea. At the beginning the idea was not "high enough" to activate a change of mind into its positronic brain, but as new conflicting information was recorded, the potential grew to a threshold point when the robot decided to change its mind and execute a very different task that was in conflict with its former task.

It somehow resonated in me as the same principle we humans work.
Sometimes we encounter two ideas that are both very appealing or very repulsing. And then we struggle to take a decision because both potentials are very even, and any light external factor can lean the decision to "the other decision" making us spend hours or days changing our minds...

But we also have snap decisions on scarce data, like the evolutionary traits of fearing a spider before truly realizing that it's actually a black lump of lint...

There's a reason nobody uses analog computers. They're not fast (in the way we think of a computer being fast) or energy efficient. In your example of the multiplication, all that current flowing through the resistor is continuously using energy. A digital computer uses some energy to do the calculation, and then it's done. And the digital computer will use less every step of the way.

As for fast, analog computers are limited by the speed of the components they're made of, just like digital. But digital computers go to great lengths to reduce inductive and capacitive loads (what limits signal speed). Analog computers don't eliminate them, they're made of them.

Analog just isn't good.

This is brilliant. Since logic gates, And, Or, Xor, etc. are analog... Creating new analog gates, like in this case, matrix multiplication. Is brilliant.


The part where he mentioned, when using a lot of gates, the outputs are distorted because tiny imperfections in analog matrix multiplication modules add up.

I wonder if instead of calculating back propagation as if the signals were perfect, with the formulas, it would be better to calculate it by solving the matrix multiplications (Doing FFNN on the actual chip), and varying a tiny bit (h) every weight on the actual analog matrix modules, so you can calculate the gradient using the oldschool derivate ( f(x+h) - f(x) ) / h for every weight. You will have a true (or almost true) gradient of the actual circuit with all its imperfections taken into account, instead of some perfect/theorical one.

Maybe doing back propagation using oldschool derivates on the actual hardware could give a less distorted signal and we could save up time by avoiding converting from digital to analog so many times.

Digital will still be the optimal way to store data. Yes, you have to deal with sampling and recreating signals if you need to store continuous information, but Shannon told us how to do that without losing information (sort of - it amounts to "not losing more information than an analog signal would lose to noise).

But for processing.. all kinds of trickery is being invented. Digital tends to be as good or better for logical operations because we tend to define logic in strict true/false terms. Analog tends to be better for differential operations because we typically invent differential operations to model the real world, and the real world is analog. Of course either one can do the other's job if you're clever enough with your design, but we're usually interested in optimized solutions more than just finding any solution.

Then we get into quantum computing which is of course best for dealing with quantum operations that can't (easily/efficiently) be done using either digital or analog computing, because nothing on a "human" scale is subject to quantum effects (and when they do occur, such as extremely small computing devices, its not controllable and thus is described as an error rather than a useful computation mechanism).

We'll probably always be using digital as the base for computing because of its ability to do general purpose things, but over the next few decades we'll probably see more and more "coprocessors" that are based on fundamentally different technology. Video cards have already been in that position for quite some time. They are of course also digital, but they don't really operate the same way that your main CPU does. That's why your video card can have thousands upon thousands of "cores" while your main processor has a dozen or less.. maybe a couple dozen if you shell out for the really high end. GPU cores are a different beast and are intentionally built to be extremely parallel like that, but they lose a lot of general purpose capabilities (despite "general purpose GPU" - GPGPU - being branded as a thing. Its more general than prior generations but it isn't going to be running Windows or macOS or Linux any time soon. Well maybe Linux. I'm sure someone somewhere has tried to port Linux to one of those things by now, though I imagine it would have to have so much cut out as to be useless for anything beyond earning cool points).

Could each neuron itself hold a memory of PATTERNS of inputs?  So in the same way that a digital computer can take a stream of 1's and 0's and interpret them serially, can a neuron take a stream of variable analog values, and process different outputs based on patterns in the analog itself? What is said in the video to be "Mythic's idea" is not a new concept. Standard flash memory stores multiple levels between 0 and 1 to increase storage density. Most advanced charge trap flash can store 16 values instead of just 0:1 in a single memory cell. This is achieved by precise tuning of the number of electrons trapped inside the floating gate (or in charge trap layer).

I started as an engineer at the Foxboro company in 1977 in a group called analog systems design. It was the early days and digital computation was slow and expensive. Foxboro had analog computers that could run on air alone, to add subtract, multiply, divide, integrate, differentiate, keep time and store values with only air pressure but not so accurate and only used for simple direct calculations in control products. Electronic analog control systems were, much faster, and more accurate for the fixed tasks the did such as PID feedback control. We had plenty of patch panel simulators with op amps programmed with banana plugs like the one Derek showed. Even today many measurements are made with analog sensing devices so A/D conversion is needed, but the flexibility of digital computation has replaced the analog controllers decades ago, even though the function block algorithms still mimic the early analog circuits. The fact that analog biologic systems like the human eye are so wonderfully complex and useful supports the conclusion that human ingenuity could mimic and enhance biologic systems with useful innovative new analog devices.

It is a little bit of a misconception that neurons are either firing or not. Often there is information in how fast are they firing per unit of time, or whether they fire in bursts or evenly or what pattern, and so on, and time synchronization is important in this. In currently popular deep models which are really high-level, the synchronization is prescribed by the feedforward/backpropagation algorithm - it's the point where you better go back to digital even with the analog implementation. But those more deep-level neural models such as Hodgkin-Huxley (which are waaay more computationally heavy than deep networks, since you are actually modelling the spike as a curve with much greater time granullarity) are also designed for analog computing. Done general enough, and more precise, this tech might bring a revolution in a wholly new direction, with practical applications.

You somewhat misunderstood the point. It's not about analog or digital it's about where computation takes place. The real paradigm is a so-called in memory computing where weights are stored in memory (either as digital or analogue) and computation is done in the same place where the weights are. This is a real energy saver since weights don't have to be moved all the time from memory to the computation unit (and in modern digital matrix vector multipliers this consumes more energy than the computation itself).
Analog vs digital is another story. Analog has two different types, partially analog where weights are stored digitally but computation is done in analog fashion or fully analog where not only computation is done in analog domain but also weights are stored as analog. In general while analog is more power efficient, computations are far less accurate requiring a lot of so-called quantization steps when signal is recovered between the layers of computation. This reduces accuracy of the computation significantly. To increase it, one needs to perform more fine grained quantization that requires more and more precise ADCs and DACs that then burn more energy so with increased accuracy the efficiency goes down. It's fairly complex topic and Mytic's approach is really not the most promising one (the most promising one is partial analog approach).
