One thing that bothers me a bit about the depiction of neurons though, is the fact they are always shown as binary (firing or not) but that's not the whole picture. A single action potential is following the all or nothing principle, so it is basically binary, but the whole neuron is relying on the frequency of these action potentials for conveying information.
Meaning a higher input strength results in a higher frequency of action potentials coming out of the neuron and vice versa.
This is an important distinction between biological and artificial neural networks.

Perceptrons “bias” value is not really the threshold, it’s simply an offset.

The equation for the perceptron can be thought as y_hat = w*x+b, where x is the input, w is weight and b is bias.
With this it becomes pretty clear that it’s a linear line in 2D inputs, (plane in 3D and hyper plane in the rest) and that the bias is really just an offset that is able to shift the threshold (line of best fit)

The perceptron will try to separate the data by essentially drawing a line of best fit (plane of best fit for 3D) through the data. If the data point is above the line, then it’s say a dog, and if it’s below the line, then it’s not a dog.
Very clever application. There are very many such developments currently being researched.

Important also to know what these tasks were that single-layer perceptrons (SLPs, those pioneered by Rosenblatt) could not solve and where these "hidden layers" come from.

The SLP was basically just a dot product as the video explained, meaning you had linear algebra. While this has its advantages in that there is a solid understanding of how to work with it, linear algebra is fundamentally limited by being, well, linear. You can think of a classification problem as trying to separate a dataset in two. You have a bunch of images represented as datapoints on a grid, and you want to draw a straight line to separate the two so that the cats on are one side and the dogs are on the other. When training an SLP, you're tuning the slope and intercept (weight and bias) of the line.

This sounds fine, but consider the problem Minsky and Papert presented: imagine a binary dataset (is this image a cat or a dog?) such that one of the sets was all on the 2nd and 4th quadrants of the grid, and the other was on the 1st and 3rd. Basically, one of the datasets was on the (+x, +y) and (-x, -y) sides and the other was on (-x, +y) and (+x, -y). How do you a draw a straight line to separate the two? The answer is you can't. Any line you draw will always have, on average, a 50% error rate, which essentially means it's a coin toss as the whether or not the "prediction" is correct. This is called the "XOR problem"

This fundamental limit to SLPs is due to their nature of being linear: because you can only draw straight lines, you can't do better than random guessing for certain tasks like the XOR problem. The solution, as it turned out, was mult-layer perceptrons, or MLPs. MLPs let neurons influence the input of other neurons by using hidden layers. This means we can draw much more complicated shapes than straight lines, allowing for these previous impossible problems to be solvable.

From doing a bit of computational neuroscience in undergrad I learned that even individual neurons are much less digital than we think. They produce spikes, yes, but the spikes are produced by voltage building up in the neuron, until it reaches some threshold, at which point biomechanical gates open and close (allowing or preventing ions to flow) to produce a rapid non-linear rise and fall in voltage, ie. spike, which is transmitted to other connected neurons. There is even a stochastic aspect to the opening and closing of these gates, which we don't yet know the full significance of computationally. This spiking behaviour also adds a temporal aspect, which isn't represented by either the digital or analogue neural networks discussed here. In most neural nets the neurons are always synced up, continuously transmitting and receiving information to and from all their connections at every time step, but in the brain one neuron may spike at 30hz and another at 25hz, or they could be the same frequency but in or out of phase, and that may itself be computationally significant.

For example, using a leaky integrate and fire model of neurons (more biologically accurate than typical neural net neurons, but not including any of the gating or non-linear spikes), connecting two excitatory neurons can result in them syncing up into phase, even if they started out of phase, and connecting two inhibitory neurons can result in them becoming 180° out of phase, even if they started in phase. In digital processors and (presumably also) the analogue processor shown here, there is a clock which syncs up operations globally and is external to those operations, but in the brain different neurons can run at different speeds and sync up with other neurons in a more local/decentralised way. And importantly, because timing can be affected by the connections between neurons, and those connections can change through learning, the timings can also change, which is not really possible with either architecture discussed here.

How computationally important are any these more fine-grained, biological details? No idea! Some are probably very important, others might just be biological implementation details. Either way, I'm personally convinced if we want AIs which approach a human level of generalised intelligence (and that's a big if), we're going to need hardware which more closely resembles the brain

Neurons are not digital! They have action potentials that fire at various strengths depending on their own state of excitation, and they have more than one 'relaxed' negative potential state after firing.

E.g. a neuron could fire at 0.3 microvolts, 0.7 micro volts, or 1.1 micro volts, and it could relax to -0.1 micro volts, or -0.4 micro volts.

A neuron also could fire depending on the accumulation of signals it recieves from other neurons.

To simplify, if one neuron was connected to 3 other neurons and it needed, say, an accumulated action potential from all three (or even from two, or just one) of atleast 1.3 micro volts for it to fire it's own potential of 1.1 microvolts to other neurons. It receives a 0.7 microvolt potential from one, 0.5 micro volts from another, and now has a combined 1.4 micro volts and will now fire at 1.1 microvolts - that may be adjusted from other inhibitory neurons, and so on. And, like those neurons that gave various strength signals, it may fire its own at various strengths depending on its level of excitation after the different signals it has recieved.

Clearly the picture is vastly more complex even than this, but the point is that neurons are not 'on or off'. They are 'fully on', 'mostly on', partially on', 'not on', 'partially relaxed', 'fully relaxed', and other states beyond even this simplified picture.

A big component that you left out is that earlier models like the perceptron were linear, they could only solve problems that were linearly separable. Modern neural networks are only capable of simulating any function because of nonlinear activation functions. There's also a few problems I see with that analog chip, namely:

1. How does learning take place when back propagation (which is little more than differentiation by parts) would need to update those weights, which in digital is a read-write operation? Is this chip meant for deploying compute-only neural networks, which don't need to be nearly as precise?
2. What is the generality of the chip? If you wanted to change what matrix you were multiplying, that'd run into a much worse von neumann bottleneck because you'd need to load every weight before computation could even begin, vs loading while computing for superscalar processors
3. How well does it scale cost-wise, since they mention that signals are digitized between chips? Depending on the parameters (speed vs accuracy) the ADC could get really pricey.

The only truly important reason digital systems are overwhelmingly dominant today is because their discrete nature allows signals to be regenerated and corrected losslessly over arbitrary distances, everything else is just convenient benefits. This both makes design tractable at scale since engineers can operate on vastly simplified abstractions when working above the transistor level (ie: assume perfect underlying logic operations), and it also allows digital system to scale to large size without errors (the primary reason the same basic design principles have worked from the 4004 with a couple thousand transistors up to modern chips with over 20 billion, and to large interconnected systems well beyond a single chip).

Neither property is available to analog computers, which means they will never see the broad and ubiquitous adoption of digital computers. Mike Henry briefly covers this at 18:56 but it's not elaborated on; it's impossible to efficiently propagate the results of an analog computation over any useful distance. This means that having specialized analog co-processors to accelerate calculations like neural network inference is entirely possible, but the "analog" bit will never extend past the perimeters of the well-controlled and well-shielded environment of a single chip.

One thing I’d add in support of analog computing is that neurons are only digital if you look at them static in time. When you look at the time domain, neurons are analog because even though they’re always either on or off, it’s their spiking frequency that actually sends a message, which looks much more like a ReLu function. It can’t increase its frequency forever, and saturates after a limit, which makes its output look more like a sigmoid, but most of the time neurons are operating in a domain far from saturation, in which their output frequency looks more like a ReLu than a sigmoid.

when it comes to AI, the imprecision in analogue actually works to its benefit. Take the first example presented in the video, the one where a computer was being trained to distiguish rectangles from circles. in a digital world, logic is binary, so if you throw a square at it, all it would know is "this is not a circle", which, while true, is incomplete. if you want to add recognition for squares, you need to add whole load of binary complexity (i.e. transistors) into the mix. An analogue machine can implement fuzzy logic directly, and make recognizing squares much easier, starting from "this is an object I know nothing about", all the way to "this is a special kind of rectangle, where every side has the same length".

A lot of the work involved in flight control is solving differential equations. Modern avionics is digital, is triplicated, and is very expensive to develop ("proving" it to be correct takes time). If the CPU you've put it on goes out of production you've got an enormous problem porting the software to a new platform. It's easy to do the porting, but you have to redo all the testing (which is where the work is).

So keeping such avionics viable for a long time is a major exercise in obsolescence management (unless the digital system happens to be implemented on a processing system that is formed out of discrete transistor packages).

Whereas, if you solve the differential equations using analogue electronics, it's far easier to demonstrate that the system is solving them correctly. The design layout follows the equation's layout, so that's simple to be sure of. After that it's a matter of calibration, largely. Better still, using nothing but transistors and passive components, it's far, far easier to manage obsolescence. As the gain of a transistor is set by the passive components around it, you're literally able to replace a blown transistor with just about any other so long as it's the right type, and meets a minimum spec.

This means that keeping analogue computers serviceable is far, far easier in the long term. You're not tied to using the exact same components as the original designers used.

I was once told that Concorde's electronics where of this happy nature - analogue systems for some parts (flight control?), and digital systems so simple (inlet control?) that they didn't use integrated circuits (just discrete transistors). The implication was that keeping Concorde's avionics operational was the easiest possible obsolescence challenge. Whereas keeping something like an F22 flyable is a major challenge with high costs.

It's not quite that clear cut; digital does allow one to do things that simply aren't very straightforward in analogue, and keeping an analogue system in calibration takes effort that is much reduced in a digital system (which simply needs its sensors / actuators checked, not the entire internals of the electronics). Noise is also an issue for analogue systems, though I liked the approach taken by that company - hopping between the digital and analogue domain a lot, to preserve signal integrity between computational stages.

So may be the ideal flight control system is an analogue computer that is wired up digitally, rather than just through wiring!

Image classification uses a convolutional neural network (CNN) at the beginning and works on tensors (volumes). This maintains spatial structures. Using an ANN with images will result in too many coefficients to learn in the first hidden layer. In CNNs each neuron is assigned a small local field of pixels called a receptive field, so not every input is connected to every neuron in the first hidden layer. Neurons apply filters which contain kernels that use the Sobel operator for edge detections on their receptive field. The filters are learnt through backpropagation and are initialized with weights either using random gaussian, Glorot/Xavier or He, methods. This all works on the pixel intensity gradient. These filters extract the features, creating feature maps (a map for each kernel in the filter). These features get sent to a pooling layer to reduce redundant features. Since the output of the pooling is a volume, it has to be flattened before it is used by the dense neural network (fully connected layer). This last layer or layers (deep neural network) is used for classification.

Efficiency? Lets take your example of adding 2 currents and multiplying them with the resistance. Yeah, that is a simple model. So? It is also simple to say "and now everybody is happy",
When it then comes to really implement that multiplication you need 2 high quality current-sources and a precision resistor as well as a precision measurement instrument to get that number. Want to use the result again? Then you now need a way to convert that voltage into a current yet again - without a significant loss in quality. It takes power, no matter if it calculates something or not.
And now lets look at a digital circuit for that: Yes, a lot more transistors are needed, but none of them need to be that precise. Further more each of them can drive a decent number of other transistors without extra circuitry. And as is a characteristics of mosfets - they basically only require power to CHANGE state and nearly nothing to maintain it.
So IF you have a continuous stream of ever changing inputs then analog can be efficient.


Also look at how INCREDIBLE efficient such simple calculations can be done:
Calculators draw in the range of microamps and still can solve differential equations.


Analog system can be very interesting for specialised applications, but they are not capable of competing for general problems and nearly always are used as a last resort cause digital solutions can not provide the bandwidth or power required (things like high power high frequency amplifiers). So training one particular neural network can be very efficient on analog systems as you do not have a specific goal for each neuron as their entire behaviour is the result of random variations. The network not needing accuracy is then again just wrong. Yes, in simple examples it does not matter if the result if 98% or 99% certainty - until the point it actually does matter and the result needs to be exact and repeatable.
And the example with the SSD - ok, so now you "only" need 1 transistor for the lossy multiplication, but docents of transistors of to generate and convert the analog signal... and you are then comparing that to a general purpose CPU that calculates the number not to an uncertain degree but accurate. A GPU like shown - sure, 100W, for "only" 2 trillion operations per second. But that is 2 trillion 32 bit operations without error. How long would it take for the analog system to produce similar accuracy? There is a reason why dedicated hardware for neural networks emerged with for lower accuracy, going as low as 4 bit multiplications. And not only that but then also equating the computational power needed for training to the application of the already trained network to a signal.

An interesting thing to note is that Quantum Computing can be thought of as a mixture of analogue and digital computation. The superposition of qubits allows for analogue computations within a quantum program (think of how the probability of being in the "1" state is a value between 0 and 1). What's interesting about quantum is that since you collapse the superposition during measurement, the output of your program is still concrete, so you don't lose precision as mentioned by the researchers in this video. Quantum algorithms like Grover's Algorithm take advantage of this this to perform faster computations, its the best of both worlds! The only issue is that no one can make a large reliable quantum computer......

Hey although you are mostly correct but when you showed Resnet and said it has 100s of layers I am feeling you have assumed that it is more layers that has resulted in the better performance. And using this concept you are saying in future we will require better computers for more deeper neural networks. However there is a flaw in your assumption. The beauty of resnet's performance is not  because of 100 or even 1000 of layers ... it is because of an architectural feature called "skip connections". Skip connections can bypass entire blocks of layers by an identity mapping. This bypass improves performance as neural networks having non linear activation functions often have difficulty in replicating an identity mapping. The beauty of Resnet is that an 100 layer Resnet can understand that the best performance  can be achieved using only 25 layers and bypass the 75 additional layers with skip connections. This also drastically reduces training times as no. of trainable weights go down and hence more computation power is not necessary. Also having more complicated neural networks with extra layers often reduce performance and overfit the data ..... So your justification that future will require deeper neural networks with greater number of computations is flawed .... it is always beneficial to have better computation power though

Ironically, the digital to analog to digital conversion means that the entire process is digital, it's just not binary digital.  The DAC that converts digital to analog has a fixed resolution.  For example, an 8-bit DAC can only create 256 different voltage levels, and an 8-bit ADC can only read 256 different voltage levels.  This means that the "analog" part is always discrete digital levels.  All you have done is create a digital system that runs on base 8 math instead of base 2 math.  ADCs and DACs can go much higher than 8-bit resolution, and would sum or multiply with a granularity that is finer than the manufacturing tolerance of the circuit, which would result in unpredictable results, which is more "analog" I guess.  However I would argue that what we want is to just focus on creating digital gates or transistors that have more than 2 states, but are still perfectly digital and reproducible.  Even a full digital computer that has 4 levels for each transistor would drastically reduce the number of gates, power requirements, and fetch latency to perform complex math.

So some quick information on this, the reason why analogs are not that good is due to many reasons, analogs actually use more power per performance then digital computers do.
There are two main issues with analog computers that I see when it comes to AI, four if you wanna include the memory and data storage.
The first main issue is that analog computers are not as accurate compared to digital computers as some might thing, although in specific cases it is.
The good thing about analog is the fact that they can provide simple data in a graphical way that doesn't require much where as digital requires complex programming and graphical programs.

One of the biggest reasons is that digital computers are able to simulate analog computers where as analog computers cannot.
Analog computers have always been a single task or single program usage this fact cannot be changed due to the systems need a specific number of switches in order to operate the voltage in a specific way.
At the end of the day we want AI to be smart, fast, analytical which is limited in analog computers, it's not that we're building them wrong it is just that analog computers are simply not enough for what true "AI" should be.

Derek - thanks for this investigation and video. I see this perspective something that is very much missing from discussion about the future of computing in general. On one hand we keep on being told that the end is in sight for Moore's law and then we get told that quantum computers will come to the rescue. This is a highly simplified view which misses out a lot of detail - classical digital computers are really great at performing certain types of tasks and will continue to serve a certain utility for the foreseeable future and the end of Moore's law is no problem here.

There are clearly things that a classical digital computer are not good at e.g. AI and here the end to Moore's law is problematic and a good reason for considering different architectures.

I have been critical of the way that reporting on quantum computers have been depicted by the media. It is obvious that we do need to focus on new computing architectures however the landscape of options is not binary like the media tend to suggest - there are many other options apart from quantum computers.

What's more, some of the less technically challenging alternative computing architectures like the analog neural network that you showcased in this video are great from a perspective that it is relatively easy to get the hardware operational which allows the R&D effort to be focused more towards the application of the technology - in this case useful neural networks.

There are many other interesting technologies in this space - photonic computers is one worth a mention.

Also I see opportunities to merge other ideas together here. Cypress Semiconductor (now part of Infineon) developed a technology that they call PSOC which is basically a merging of FPGA programmability with analog circuitry - if this is applied to analog computer architecture then maybe we can design highly generalized analog computing architecture.

I also think that digital computers can be developed considerably based on the more than Moore concept. I.E., once we run out of performance improvements that can made from moving to finer ASIC geometries then there is likely to be more focus placed on what else can be done at an architectural level to gain performance improvements - something that is being overlooked based on the Moore's law path being identified as the lowest hanging fruit.

Some years ago as I was finishing up on my computer science education, I had to do a project for my finals (this is not university, btw, just a secondary kind of route available to me in my country) and I had always been fascinated by artificial intelligence and neural networks, so I picked to do something in that realm. I never had anything to do with AI prior to that, so my knowledge was quite shallow when it came to how artificial neural networks actually work. I had been programming for quite some time at that point so I had my basic tools in place, so to say, but I really didn't know where to start from there when it came to what I picked as a "task" I wanted to solve by this method.
The task I picked was driving a little simulated 2D-car along a randomly generated road without any human input and unfortunately, the language I was most proficient in at the time was Java, so I tried to implement it in Java.
When I first started the project, I read a lot about neural networks and even included some scientific papers on it in my reading, but not stemming from any kind of scientific background, I really struggled to understand the deeper concepts presented in those, which eventually lead me to just abandon reading up on the topic and just approach it with the general concept of "How could/would it work?".
Looking back, I think I have never in my life experienced a time when I was more challenged by a task I set out to complete and also never before I was thinking that much about how our brains actually process information, as that is the key idea behind it. Yet, slowly but surely, I ended up with a pretty similar concept to what most neural networks do, even though probably far less efficient than using something that was already available like TensorFlow.
Where am I going with this story? Well, after a while it actually worked, the little network I created "learned" how to drive the car along the road after countless iterations of doing it wrong and to this day, it just absolutely blew my mind on so many levels that this was possible. Even more so considering that all of these complex processes take place in our brains every microsecond we exist with much more proficiency. I absolutely loved that project from beginning to end and if not for the rest of that educational path I took and years of aimlessly programming for fun, it just made me know that I truly love the entire concept of using programming to recreate something in nature.

I would modify your last comment a little bit to say that, perhaps the future of computers is like the brain, both digital (neuron firing) and analog (synapse weights): ergo, "Digilog." ... The need for switching back and forth between analog and digital processes in the final example to address the noise issue wasn't entirely clear to me vis-a-vis the brain. The best I make of it is that, architecturally, they are implementing a series of matrix multiplications through all the layers of their neural network. Whereas, the brain's neurons simply take an input vector and compares the sum of its components to a threshold value. Whereupon it outputs a 1 or a 0. The neuron doesn't care care how far above or below the threshold the incoming signal is. That's the brains A-D conversion process. The neuron throws out scads of input information in the process, but the output signal is not vague. This may be the trading-off precision for simplicity (i.e., efficiency; also,the principle of occam's razor). Certainly, the brain processes in a noisy environment. Thermal noise must be there, and I wouldn't be surprised to find other strong sources of noise. This is a Shannon noisy channel coding problem. Focusing on the links (neural axons) rather than the nodes (neurons) the brain is a massive signal transmission system. ... Very, very well done video (as always). Much appreciated.

Rosenblatt’s Perceptron was essentially a one-neuron network, although he could perform logical operations on the binary data inputs before passing results, which gave it more power.
Minsky and Papert at MIT were concerned that Rosenblatt was making extravagant claims for his Perceptron and scooping up a lot of the available funding.
In their book, “Perceptions”, Minsky & Papert proved that one-neuron networks were limited in the tasks they could perform.
You could build networks with multiple Perceptions, but since Perceptrons had binary outputs, nobody could think of a way to train networks.
That killed funding for neural networks for decades.
In the late 1980s, interest was re-kindled when John Hopfield, a physicist, came up with a training technique that resembled cooling of a physical spin-glass system.
But the big breakthrough came when the error back-propagation technique was developed by Rumellhart, Hinton &Williams.
In this, neurons were modified to have a continuous non-linear function for their outputs, instead of a thresholded binary output.
Consequently, outputs of the network were continuous functions of the inputs and weights.
A hill-climbing optimisation process could then be used to adjust weights and hence minimise network errors.
The rest is history.

Part of the way smartphones, gpus, and cpus are being made faster and more efficient today is by implementing specialized hardware for certain tasks. GPUs were made as a specialized piece of hardware for graphics rendering when cpus weren't progressing their generalized toolset fast enough. Now phones are coming with dedicated AI/neural net chips to lower power consumption and speed up those tasks. I can easily imagine something like that 3W chip (or something made from the ground up) being implemented to speed up tasks like image processing for cameras, dedicated local AI assistant processing, and other tasks I cannot think of. Digital's repeatability is a must have for many tasks (when you run billions of operations a second continuously you cannot afford to compound errors) but analog may be implemented into GPUs where tasks and data isn't compounded for too long (you don't need to process an image in a game for more than a microsecond, it doesn't matter if its only 99% accurate, and very little if any future calculations are based off of that calculation.) Analog can break into more fields closer to consumers than quantum computing, but we'll always need the solid foundation of digital unless we can drastically reduce the margin of error in analog.

I've been involved in this field for over thirty years, and the analog stuff is great (read about Carver Mead at Cal Tech), but analog doesn't solve the big challenges of AI. If you distill the current AI offerings down to their essence - what they are doing is really just advanced signal processing (or image processing).  There is no intelligence there.  All of the networks are modeled after the perceptron, but the perceptron is a hyper-simplified model of a neuron from the visual cortex.  There are thousands of different types of neurons in the mammalian brain and the ones for motor control (for example) are structured nothing like a perceptron.  One thing current AI enthusiasts miss about intelligence is that life is a continuum, not a static point.  A humans sense of 'the moment' , what is referred to as your episodic memory, includes a lot of contextual aspects that don't have discrete values you can use as inputs to a neural network.  The representation of these combinatoric but immanent qualities and how they are internalized and relate to one another, and ultimately produce behavior is an example of a real AI challenge.

There is no way that we use analog computers for ACID compliant data basing, addition or subtraction, or really anything that requires precision.
If you look into floating point computation however, there is absolutely a fantastic use case for values computed by analog and operated on by digital processes.
In software development, the usage of floats is minimized whenever possible, we run into rounding errors and general numeric issues when dealing with high decimal precision.
According to IEEE 754 (binary64), other than the sign bit, 11 out of the 63 remaining bits are reserved exclusively for the exponent. A comically large portion of the bitstring totally devoted to the scale of the float, whilst not actually denoting the 15 to 17 significant digits.

Multiplication/Division on analog PCI card would be fantastic in general purpose computing.
If you want to learn more, read on binary division/multiplication, even then multiplication is faster than division on a digital computer.

We do however have some tricks up our sleeve, like shifting a bit to the right to divide it by 2, or to the left to multiply by 2.
To sum it up (pun intended): calculate analog, transport digital.

4:52 NO! This is wrong! It is NOT how real neurons work, not even close. For starters, each neuron can collect multiple signals from the same input BEFORE deciding whether to fire or not. Second, the neuron has an internal mechanism of feedback, looping back its signal. Third, other neurons can affect that loop-back mechanism too.

This video is quite disingenuous. The comparison Veritasium here is laying in front of us is the comparison between general purpose computing and analog computing like this is something new that is emerging. That we currently are starting to understand that general purpose computing might not be the solution for everything.  It's already known for decades that for real-time processing of data, implementation is always a trade-off between configurability and throughput(speed). Within digital computing these concepts also exists in the form of GPUs, FPGAs and ASICs. We can already solve the Von Neumann Bottleneck within these systems, since these devices provide the freedom where and how to allocate memory. These analog chips might be really good at this specific purpose within AI, but integrated circuitry is anything but new or exciting. I think it's quite the bummer. These video's where normally well informed and researched, but since diving into the field of electrical engineering, mistakes are being made left and right. The error of confusing analog computing with computing parallelism at the end, is unforgivable in an educational video with a reach of this size.

I can't agree with some of the mentioned statements.

Moore's Law was mentioned in the wrong context. The number of transistors doubles and so the performance should double. But this Law is wrong for many years. CPUs with multiple cores, increased parallelization of tasks and specialized computation units like in the ARM world has shown that increasing the transistors isn't the only way to increase the compute power of a digital machine. Yes, there is a physical limit how small a transistor can get, but there are new transistor forms to solve this problem like CasFET.

The second statement that is not quite correct was by the CEO of Mythic. He shows a GPU and states that it can compute 10-20 trillion operation per seconds. This is right - but so does a Snapdragon or A14 from Apple with much much lower power usage. His product is not faster than an ARM based digital processor. It can be more power efficient, but only a few watts. Virtual Reality already uses this digital processors to compute the kinematics in real time. The problem is not the local processing power he wants to solve.

The third statement was that smaller inaccuracies are okay to accept - but only for the final product. Any error a long the line for deep neuron networks will cascade and create a big error in the end. Digital computers also have the problems because of their floating number arithmetic - they can use a slower, but more accurate computation model to minimize the error.

Also the downside of using the flash cells was not stated - flash cells degenerated over time, so the analogue computer will die some time? Yes, SSDs with their flash cells have a long life now, but because they don't read / write cells all the time and have some backup cells they switch to.

The shown examples couldn't convince me that analogue computers will have a bigger part in the market. They will solve some tiny problems with specialized and expensive hardware that may be a bit more power efficient.

I can understand it that you cannot go in detail about everything in just a 20 minute youtube video - but I expected some more in depth analysis and commentary when you say, that "We're Building Computers Wrong" - even for AI.

Even if this "1% error" is correct*, errors propagate, though cascade may be the better term here!
If you switch back and forth between digital and analog, each switch introduces more chance for a cutoff of potentially significant digits.
Even a one percent error, each time carried over and reintroduced through thousands of operations makes the computation pointless. Even 0.01% would be hard to argue for.
I don't think that this makes sense from an AI Safety perspective. And that is the most relevant perspective, if you are considering massively increasing the power of a potentially intelligent and likely misaligned agent.

*I believe that most analog parts have an error bar that is closer to the 5-10% mark, though the presented system is not a "normal" part in this regard, necessarily.

Where it has a lot more options than just 0 or 1, but it's not continuously variable and instead has steps (as analog technically means it can occupy any value between the endpoints, which is part of why the limitations on accuracy come into play). The quantum processors are more likely to fall into this category, where they get trained to have more than 2 states, but still will need to be limited to specific set step values. Incorrectly ?

"Analog" does not mean to process multiple pieces of data at the same time!
"Analog" means having a continuous spectrum of values - as opposed to a discrete set of values aka "digital"
What you're referring to at the end is called "parallel processing". It does not matter if your computer is digital or analog to be capable of parallel processing.

Also: "neurons" as used in the perceptron are just a very crude approximation of real biological neurons. Our Brains actually work on an analog time based processing scheme where different intensities are related to the firing rate of neurons. So even though, they can only "fire or not fire" the overall computation actually happens in the analog domain.

Even more: real neurons have various side channel signaling like hormones etc.

What I am interested in, is the plasticity of the system. As an AI Engineer, you have to constantly change you hyperparameter, maybe even topology or architecture. That's why general computing is so useful, I can just as easily run a RNN on my machine as a CNN or BERT, because I can adapted the computational pathways. I am not sure how that would work in analog computers, since like you said, the current get's added up. It is definitly an interesting thing to think about, but right now, most of AI is crazy fast in developement, something that was state of the art last year can be outdated today. AlexNet and ResNet have also been toppled in CV applications and BERT has taken over most of the domain of NLP problems since 2019.

In this field, there are two way of getting better results: throw more data at the problem and make the models bigger or make new models, that are better suited for the task. If you could just improve by scaling up everything, analog computers might be a good contender for AI problems, but I think, we are still in the phase of figuring out better topologies for certain problems and for that, general computing will probably still be better.

this video was very hit or miss for me. As someone who is currently working on Machine Learning projects in finance where accuracy is everything, it seems that the "gating" system they use (passing one analogue answer into another analogue system) to reduce the error in analogue computers doesn't really satisfy the need that all AI requires. I think its great for the aforementioned use cases like pre-trained identification systems. However, for building an AI and training it to be accurate to within say 10% (depending on application, I'm basing this off my experience with finance) still seems best suited to cards like the A100 a 300 teraflop (300 trillion floating point operations per second) AI processing monster.

I think at best its a fair way off, I don't think it would be right to say that it would be impossible by any stretch of the imagination, but I think right now it would be disingenuous to say it is the certain future for AI based on the issues that you brought up.

You said the brain is digital, but that is not completely correct. Yes, a neuron firing or not is digital. However, when a neuron fires is not digital. There is a large amount of different factors that influence whether or not that neuron will fire. From intracellular chemistry, to the composition of the fluid around the neuron and even genetic factors. Furthermore, the firing of a neuron doesn't always give a response in the next neuron, depending on a similar miriade of factors.  I would say that the brain is a complex (of course) combination of digital and analogue.

Networks that use the amount of electricity that you state (the yearly use of 3 households) are exceptional. The thing is that scaling up a model to increase results is a flawed method to begin with. It is brute forcing your way through a problem at the cost of efficiency, customizability and transparancy. I am in the field of natural language processing and applying ridiculously huge general models to problems is definitely the trend in the more impactful papers. In the industry however, the trend is still to apply purpose-built and designed-for-efficiency models. The same problems that could be solved by the 175 billion parameter model GPT-3, can sometimes be solved by a simple statistical method yielding a slightly less impressive result.

To make an analog computer is to predict the future, and it means that it is not gonna be very versatile. Though it is fast, the price is general compatibility with a lot of things, many changes needed to be made, but it might be the kind of changes we need to get a more efficient computing mechanism

Great video, but this is not new. What you are essentially reffering in this video is specialized hardware for a specific task. These kind of chips can contain all kinds of circuitry from digital to analogue. The thing is for over 50 years we have just chucked a CPU or GPU againsta a certain task because they are for general purpose this means that they are very flexible software, but what you are essentially doing with the "analog computer" is hardware programming for a specific task. So if this is better suited in the analog domain than yes an analog circuit is better. I think because  CPU's and GPU's are going to reach a limit we are going to see more specialized hardware be it analog or digital depends on the task at hand.
